denilson wrote: buy a used haswell era laptop with hdd and put ssd inside? +1. Trying not to sound like a fanboy, but Thinkpads come straight to mind. IMO, used Haswell Thinkpads give the best bang for buck right now; they're not too old yet, and those bought with extended warranty might even still be under warranty. They age gracefully anyway, unless abused really hard by the previous owner(s). Many of them also have vacant M.2 slots (no NVMe for this gen though, only SATA), so you can add a fast boot drive without having to spend a ton on a high capacity 2.5" SSD.

Comes with backpack, $30 steam credit, 2 years onsite warranty from Dell and coverage for accidental damage. I'll save the Aftershock fan boys the trouble and say that yes with that price I could have bought the 1070 S-17 but that card draws a whopping 210 watts of power! With so much heat produced in a thin chassis and virtually no review or benchmark of the machine performing under load and to see how effective its heat dissipation is, I'm not too optimistic about the longevity of those machines. 1060 maybe, but not the 1070. Picked Alienware cause they didn't skimp on their thermal management. I want the most bang for my buck.

Usually dont post but, the alienware thermals are REALLY REALLY BAD. readup notebookreview user forum and youtube search. alienware is the worst this gen and last gen. msi, aorus, asus, aftershock etc with thinner and lighter chasis performs better thermals then alienware. buy alienware for build and lighting. not for thermals.

teckhwee wrote: Usually dont post but, the alienware thermals are REALLY REALLY BAD. readup notebookreview user forum and youtube search. alienware is the worst this gen and last gen. msi, aorus, asus, aftershock etc with thinner and lighter chasis performs better thermals then alienware. buy alienware for build and lighting. not for thermals. If you're talking about the uneven core temperatures affecting the cpu, it was due to the thick thermal pads Alienware was using and has since been reaolved by Dell since December. That same forum on notebookreviews would tell you that. Disagree with regards to the Asus GL502 and 702 as they've been complaints by users in the Rog forums of excess heat throttling their cpus and gpus. I think the trade off for portability over thermal management shouldn't be so steep especially with such an expensive machine and why buy a machine only to have it neutered right out of the box. Of course with the G752, the thermals would probably be better (I wouldn't know because I can't afford that series hence no research) but you're also paying about 3.9k for their base line machine in that bracket according to the brochure. I had a MSI Ghost Pro before but the chassis got really hot during gaming. It's cpu and gpu were within acceptable temp ranges but I had to undervolt the cpu to get there. Hopefully the newer models are better. Never checked the Aorus out.

IT/PC Shows - How to further reduce the price of your laptop (1) Reject all freebies - Ask for the best price they can give after taking away all the peripherals. (2) Offer to pay in cash only - Only do this step after the above is done. Ask for a further discount. The vendor can save on credit card transaction cost (this is inclusive of NETS too). You may want to highlight this to the sales representative, or ask him to ask his supervisor. (3) Wait for the last day - It's a risky move, as you may not get the model you want. The vendors usually prefer to sell off all their products at the show than to bring it back to their shops (additional cost to transport the unsold products back). So they will reduce the price further for visitors to snap them up.

As mod of the Notebook Clinic as well, I do occasionally receive questions regarding processors and their differences. Contrary to what some promoters have said in my years of visiting such tech shows - Not all i7 processors are the same - and there are Quad and Dual core variants available. Without going into the specifics since this is a buying guide after all, I shall just write the key things you need to take note of when buying a laptop (Intel & Nvidia based laptops) CPU: 1. Types of Processors Quote: There are 3 types of Processors are from Intel. They are the Intel i3, i5, i7 As a general rule of thumb, i7 is better than i5 which is better than i3 This is due to a variety of factors such as amount of cores, clock speed,  amount cache and turbo boost. With the exception of i3 CPU(s) which are only dual core, Both the i5 and i7 CPU(s) have dual and quad variants - though on the market, most i5 notebooks are dual cored. The later sections of this thread will explain how to tell the differences when you are looking at the specifications sheet to determine if it's a quad or dual core. 2. Naming Structure Quote: Let's take 3 Processors for instance. An Intel i7 6700HQ, i5 5200U & Intel i7 4720MQ 4720MQ 4 signifies that it is a 4th Generation MQ indicates that it is a Quad Core processor that is socketed and can be removed /replaced without changing the entire motherboard 5200U 5 signifies that it is a 5th Generation U indicates Ultra Low Voltage and Dual Core 6700HQ 6 signifies that it is a 6th Generation Processor HQ indicates Quad core processor that's soldered on to the motherboard. Quick tip! Q = Quad , U = Dual. 3. Do I need a Quad core or is Dual Core sufficient for my usage? Quote: This is a question that I am often asked the most and it has to depend on your usage patterns. A Dual Core U processor laptop is sufficient for most day to day usage situations - i.e. Web surfing, Report Writing, Light Gaming*, Video watching... A Quad Core Q processor is needed when you dwell into things that requires multi tasking - i.e. Rendering/ Photo-Video Editing. Being mobility devices, there is a trade off between performance and battery life with the rule of thumb being that a quad core processor would have better performance but slightly lesser battery life than a dual core processor. *Light gaming on titles such as Left 4 Dead 2 - on mid settings. GPU: 1. Types of GPU Quote: There are two types of graphics which can be found on one's notebooks Dedicated / Discrete and Integrated. Dedicated GPUs have built in memory onto it's card / chip, while Integrated GPUs uses memory from the laptop's ram - shared memory. Performance wise - though having said that there are performance improvements of Integrated GPUs over the years, Dedicated GPUs still do out perform Integrated GPUs. 2. Dedicated Graphics (Nvidia) Quote: GT - indicates consumer end with M indicating it to be a mobile GPU chip. First number indicates series / gen GT940M = 9th Gen Middle number indicates grade / range. Numbers from 1 to 3 indicate Low / Low mid range. Examples of low end mobile GPUs are GT920M Numbers 4 to 5 indicates Mid to Mid High Examples of mid range mobile GPUs are GT940M , GT950M Numbers 6 to 8 are often GTX series that offers high performance GTX - indicates enthusiast grade GPU. Examples are GTX960M, GTX970M 2. Which should I get Dedicated or Integrated? Quote: Similar to the dual vs quad core processor comparison, the same argument applies to dedicated vs integrated graphics. It boils down to usage patterns as well as the performance to battery life trade off. I would suggest getting a dedicated graphics owing to the flexibility of software and applications that can be done with having on board dedicated graphics.

Great guide. I think there are some other explanations of letters/etc available handily on the Intel website: http://www.intel.sg/content/www/xa/e...r-numbers.html Is it possible to add some explanation on what Atom, Celeron, Pentium mean and how it impacts users? I think it might be a good idea to help set expectations because I have seen some less than honest salespeople at these types of events hyping up the 'relativity' of different processors (e.g. Atom x is 'newer' and 'quad core' therefore it's better than an i5 dual core).

Multi tasking can be done on a Quad atom - however there is a perform limit to it before it crawls and the limit is much much lower than an i5. Celeron / Pentium: For Entry level Notebooks Core M:  Performance sandwiched between i series (Upper) and Atom/Celeron/Pentium (Lower) processors. HardwareZone Forums app

Show Highlights! ====================================================================== Tech lovers are in for a treat this week, as both the CEE Show and PC Show are happening at the same time from June 1 to 4. Here are a few questions / things you should check & ask before purchasing a new printer: Check List: Quote: C1. Do I need a printer that can print on both sides of a page? If Yes* - you would need a Duplex Printer. *Technically: You can print dual sided using a non duplex (single sided) printer as well - pointed out by a fellow forumer here - by printing single sided and flipping it the other way. For convenience, and the relatively low cost of Duplex printers however, it might be more convenient to purchase a Duplex Printer instead if you are a medium to heavy user who utilise duplex printing often. Do weigh the pros, cons and costs before considering either options. C2. Am I printing black & white pages mostly and minimal / no colour If Yes - Get a monochrome printer. If No - Get a laser colour / colour inkjet. Though colour lasers and laser printers in general have dropped in price, it is still expensive to purchase and to run too - there would be 4 toners in total - 3 for colours (Cyan, Magenta, Yellow) , and 1 for black. C3. Do I need wireless printing or would it be plugged in to a stand alone PC and forgotten? Wireless printing works by sending your prints over your connected network then to the printer which then prints your queued document. It is more convenient if you have multiple users co sharing a printer i.e. home printer placed in a centralised location. All wireless printers have I/O for conventional usb printing should you need them. C4. Would it be cheaper to purchase a printer or print it at shops? Here are a few cost criterias that you would have to consider. 1. Toner costs - they do cost a fair bit but make it up in terms of pages that can be printed before toner replacement - certainly more affordable than an ink jet, and hey being a powder, it doesn't "dry" out like its ink counterparts. 2. Drum / Photo conductor cost - a drum is basically the component that picks up images and then transfers this image on to the paper. It lasts considerably longer than a toner - probably 3 - 5 times longer before needing to be replaced. In general a rule of thumb would be to. Take the cost of the toner and divide it by its page yield. For instance, a particular toner costs $90 and has a yield of 2600 pages. $90 / 2600 pages equals to $0.035 per page printed (Excluding paper, Drum per page costs and assuming negligible electrical cost ). C5. Do I need an ALL IN ONE? (Scan / Copy) A scanner can be useful at times for digitizing our documents such as receipts etc / quick duplication of documents. Good to have but adds to cost. Questions you should ask before purchasing. Quote: Q1. How many pages can this printer print? Q2. What is the toner yield and also is there any high yield toners available   for this model? Q3. How many pages later would the drum of the toner need to be replaced and at what cost? Q4. Lastly, any freebies? and got trolley? Hope this guide helps you out.

mac_oasis wrote: Hi all, for laser printers is it better to purchase with separate toner and drums or toner and drums as 1? Please answer this !

Everett_ wrote: Please answer this ! You have to look at the cost. In conventional laser printers, Drums and Toners are separate entities, i.e. to say that after 3 - 6 toner replacements would that you would then require 1 drum replacement. In some sense, it might be cheaper. A couple of formulas i typically use to calculate my costs are as follows - Formula 1: Toner cost / Toner yield (how many pages it can print)  to get cost per page. Formula 2: Assumption: 5 toner changes = 1 drum change. 5 x toner cost + 1 drum cost / Total yield (yield of 5 toners) For your case, if you were to pick an integrated toner and drum -  use formula 1.  Then compare it with formula 2 for the same page yield for a separate toner - drum printer hope this helps

This is our new one-stop forum for everything and anything related to the local tech shows! From the big mega fairs like IT Show, CEE, PC Show, COMEX, CEF and SITEX, all the way to the various weekly IT fairs around Singapore that are brought to you by Audio House, Best Denki, Challenger, Courts, Gain City, Harvey Norman and much much more! With this new format, we intend to keep the relevant discussions going for a longer time. This will serve as a valuable reference point for any new upcoming show as a wealth of recommendations, discussions and tips have been shared in volume by several members. We don't intend to close and open new tech show forums with this format. With every major upcoming tech show, we'll append the show name in brackets, like the coming CEE show and PC Show, as an indicator of what's coming. Feel free to contribute and discuss the latest tech deals available anywhere across Singapore. Some notes:- Referrals are not allowed. WTS/WTB should be kept strictly in marketplace. This forum is dedicated to shows and deals from physical stores, expos, shops. Please keep it as such. Meanwhile, for long-time contributors of our show forums, if you recall participating in exhaustive and useful discussion threads in the past that you feel have good value for this new permanent forum at this point of time, please feel free to link us up to consider moving them over here. Thank you and let the sharing begin!

keith wrote: Possible, the katana outputs LFE at high level via RCA to its own sub, so ideally i should just: RCA -> hi-to-low level converter -> MW550 sub i tried direct, but is loosing too much signals. keith Just increase the sub volume higher on your Katana This may be hard to believe, but RCA full-scale output voltage is 2Vrms which is actually higher than what most people run their speakers outputs at. 2V would give at least 80dB on most speakers which is hearing safety hazard levels.

wwenze wrote: Just increase the sub volume higher on your Katana This may be hard to believe, but RCA full-scale output voltage is 2Vrms which is actually higher than what most people run their speakers outputs at. 2V would give at least 80dB on most speakers which is hearing safety hazard levels. hi, i am not sure if the katana sub amp drives its own sub at 2Vrms (Hi level) only? can share on this point? for HT or car audio, I am sure you cant mix hi n lo levels.

Justanewbie wrote: Hooted. Sounds good and loud. Bass is decent as well. Thought someone said no stock.
Hooted it yesterday. Saw quite a few sets in the booth.

keith wrote: hi, i am not sure if the katana sub amp drives its own sub at 2Vrms (Hi level) only? can share on this point? for HT or car audio, I am sure you cant mix hi n lo levels. Max volume? Probably higher. However don't forget your MW550 sub also has its own volume control. The Katana's volume control already reduce the volume before feeding to Katana's speakers and sub out, so the sub out volume is already (max voltage) minus (god knows how many dB). Then your MW550's own volume control takes that signal and minus (another god knows how many dB). So of course you will feel the volume is very low. In this kind of situation, the volume control of the receiving speaker (i.e. MW550) needs to be set to 0dB if you want the sub to be at the same loudness as the Katana speakers. This usually means at least 12 o'clock on the volume control and usually 2-3 o'clock.

wwenze wrote: Max volume? Probably higher. However don't forget your MW550 sub also has its own volume control. The Katana's volume control already reduce the volume before feeding to Katana's speakers and sub out, so the sub out volume is already (max voltage) minus (god knows how many dB). Then your MW550's own volume control takes that signal and minus (another god knows how many dB). So of course you will feel the volume is very low. In this kind of situation, the volume control of the receiving speaker (i.e. MW550) needs to be set to 0dB if you want the sub to be at the same loudness as the Katana speakers. This usually means at least 12 o'clock on the volume control and usually 2-3 o'clock. hi, i think my situation is much simpler... Katana's outup (to sub) is at hi-level, meaning it is able to drive the sub's coil directly. And If I were to feed this signal to a lo-level input of the MW550. I dont think thats going to work well. Otherwise, there would not be hi-to-lo converters in the market, or also why some AMPs have hi-level inputs, while others just the usual lo-level ones. Also not to mention the risk of burning my inputs to my MW. So i dont think its possible to connect directly from katana -> MW550, without a level converter or w/o signal attenuation. cheers

Hi-to-lo converters? Yea they exist because there are situations where the amp is outputting >2V and you cannot change that. But if you're feeling the volume is too low means the amp is outputting too low a voltage even for driving the MW550 sub and you need to increase it. You're right, the situation is much simpler and post #14 already has a 1-liner solution.

Plenty of discussions about DVB-T2 and digital TV on some other threads in HWZ forums, check them out for lots of info based on actual experiences. Was using Draco HDT2-7300 for few years, worked well until conked out recently, unable to receive any signal (checked using other antennas so not antenna problem). Now they're selling a newer 7700 model, dunno if any better. The supplied Draco antenna (ANT-600A) is useless, couldn't pick up anything. Other minor quibble: Draco interface rather clunky, remote control buttons squeezed together so may accidentally press wrong button. Currently using Hyundai HDV-360 bought thru Qoo10 for 30 bucks, works great. Minor notes: doesn't come with any antenna, USB port at back of STB (inconvenient if plugging in & out frequently), remote con has tiny buttons and white lettering on light gray buttons makes it difficult to see which button. Dunno about other branded STBs but heard New Media Solutions one has copy protection ie cannot watch recorded programmes using other devices like PC. Actually think almost all STBs are much the same, more crucial is the antenna. Best is if on high floor, no surrounding high buildings and near to window, then cheap passive antenna also can. Those who like tinkering with stuff can try making DIY antenna, just google for instructions: personal experience from best to worst is dual bow-tie, coat hanger, fractal, binder clip. DIY antenna can be active if in STB settings select antenna power to be on. Don't look down on DIY antenna, their performance can thrash expensive store bought ones. Also note performance of any antenna can be affected by things like bad weather, interference from devices like amps & routers etc. If results still unsatisfactory or die die must have 100% always reliable signal, then no choice but buy good active antenna. Haven't used Daiyo ones so no comment but Funke Combo 5.1 is impressive. Can have smooth video even if signal quality in single digits for passive mode. Certainly best solid performance is as active antenna (USB adapter thingy is supplied), both signal quality & performance at 100%; I'm at low floor with TV almost 5m from window.

Just a share on wireless earphones.. And so I braved the crowds at the IT SHOW in search of a wireless sport (sweat resistant) earphone which would basically fulfill three needs: 1. Does not fall from the ear easily. 2. Comfortable on the ear. 3. Decent sound quality (SQ) . The following were tried out: 1. Jabra Rox 2. Plantronics Go 3 3. Jaybird Freedom F5 - Smallest battery lifespan but the most comfortable and great SQ. 4. Creative Outlier Sport - best value for $ with Citibank CC. 5. Bose SoundSport - Great SQ. And the overall winner goes to... Jaybird Freedom! Light, stays in my ear (more so with their Comply earbuds, I dont even have to use the ear hook), not so protruding out from the ears, and great (and customisable) SQ. Downside is the battery life of course, but 4hrs (without the battery charger device connected) is adequate for my usage. From the start, I was sceptical of wireless earphones as they seem ever ready to fall out from my smaller than average ears anytime and I am glad I was wrong after trying out all the above. Emphasis on trying out as each person's ear anatomy and musical perception is different. Don't be shy to ask for a demo set to try out. If the ear buds are too big or small for your ear, ask for one which fits. All of the sales staff at the booths are patient and friendly, big thumbs-up to them especially the guy at Jaybird Best Denki booth.

Hi, Just to share, might want to consider this also: https://www.solrepublic.com/shadow-w...earphones.html Got it for $149 from http://www.twobros.com.sg/locate-our-store Think it's much more comfortable than freedom and good quality too with water and sweat resistant.

Seems like Orbi is now a true Mesh WIFI with the latest update... Announcing the availability for OrbiOS 2.0. This release includes 2 community requested features that we're happy to deliver: 1) Daisy Chain - which allows Orbi Satellites to talk to each other.  This extends the reach of the Orbi system, especially in long or tall floorplans. 2) Improvements to the Attached Device page, which will now show which Orbi each device is connected to, and over which frequency (2.4 or 5GHz).  This page also shows how each Orbi Satellite's upstream Orbi is. 3) Due to field feedback, we've brought back the Radio Transmit Power control 4) Allows you to rename devices & your Orbi Satellites via orbilogin It also has many bug fixes and incremental improvements

Quote: Multi-user, multiple-input, multiple-output technology\x97better known as MU-MIMO (a.k.a. Next-Gen AC or AC Wave 2)\x97allows a Wi-Fi router to communicate with multiple devices simultaneously. This decreases the time each device has to wait for a signal and dramatically speeds up your network. Considering that the average household has upwards of eight devices battling for bandwidth simultaneously, MU-MIMO will increasingly improve your Wi-Fi experience. For home Wi-Fi users, annoyances such as choppy video and continual buffering can really put a damper on the fun, but anyone who uses a Wi-Fi network will benefit from the performance improvements of MU-MIMO. Here are some of the ways MU-MIMO kicks common Wi-Fi problems to the curb: Both MU-MIMO and non-MU-MIMO (SU-MIMO) devices operate faster because all devices on the network have less time to wait to get data from the Wi-Fi router. MU-MIMO technology increases the capacity and efficiency of your router, allowing it to handle more Wi-Fi-intensive activities such as streaming and gaming.

You can, but it would mean you'll be managing two SSIDs - one by the mesh, the other by the StarHub router. You could of course just use the mesh network's SSID for all your wireless needs. axay72 wrote: Possible I purchased my own Mesh Wi-Fi Device and hook up with Starhub fiber router , does it work ?

All of them have such lofty claims. It's assuming you live in a large landed property like in a US suburb - airy large house, with few concrete walls if any at all. Sure, the one device can service the whole house and even the garden. In an urban jungle like Singapore, you live in much smaller homes, much closer in proximity to your neighbors and likely have a very congested network channel. Not to mention there's a bomb shelter in every home, concrete walls, and walls that are in close proximity of each other, thereby making it difficult for wireless signals to propagate. So nevermind those marketing figures. Whether to buy a mesh networking router or a normal router depends on your available infrastructure and don't mind being more savvy to fine tune the router configurations. If your home has some LAN points laid out, it becomes a lot easier to consider multiple routers, assuming you're fine in dabbling with router configurations. That scenario aside, mesh networking systems can really help you 1) set up a wireless network with ease, 2) be able to place the nodes as you see wish to eliminate wireless dead spots. However, not all mesh networking systems are alike and that's why we did a basic 101 on this topic:- http://www.hardwarezone.com.sg/featu...esh-networking PsyClick wrote: Can someone help explain to a non tech person. If netgear Orbi claim their coverage is up to 6000 sqft, isn't it too much for people who lives in average of 1000 sqft hdb? If I am just need my 1000sqft hdb to have good coverage of wifi, do you guys recommend 2x router or still mesh? Thanks

Dr.Vijay wrote: You can, but it would mean you'll be managing two SSIDs - one by the mesh, the other by the StarHub router. You could of course just use the mesh network's SSID for all your wireless needs. So, the better solution is to either: (1) Remove the StarHub Router and connect the Mesh Router directly to the Modem/ONT (For Fibre, you might need to call StarHub to disable MAC ID Filtering so you can use any Router), OR (2) Disable WiFi on StarHub Router and connect the Mesh Router to the StarHub Router as a Access Point/Bridge

Thanks essentially both are supporting the same wifi speed class of 2x2, wireless AC. However the significant difference is that ac1200g+ has 4 5dBi antennas outside while ac56u has internal antennas for wifi. coverage will be lower comparing to ac1200g+. whether which device suits you the most depends on your location of placement of router. 5 rm flat by right should go better with an external antenna one, which i suggest ac1200g+. I won't rule out the fact ac56u can support adequate coverage for 5rm flat, but again, i'm suggesting based on common sense.

Think AC1200g+ will provide better 5GHz coverage due to the external antenna. However, AC56U has better processor, also got 2 USB ports ( with 1 USB 3.0 ), so u can connect more stuff like HDD and 3G dongle or printer etc U might wanna check out this review ( http://www.digitalcitizen.life/revie...-can-buy-today ) , which also compared it to AC56U. If u want better 5GHz coverage, I think AC1200g+ is quite good

I would suggest you having a ac1200 for the main router point and a ac56u in the furthest bedroom. I have installed a few routers in hdbs. The walls and the interference of multiple wifi signals usually the wifi signal will drop drastically once out of line of sight. Having a ac56 in the bed room, it will reduce the number of dead zones. If you are in the new hdbs, try convert the telephone to lan. Connect the ac56 via this lan connection.

I think there is a misconception here. m.2 is merely a connection type. m.2 can be both SATA or PCIe NVMe. If your m.2 SSD is SATA, it is no different from a 2.5" SATA SSD, except of course, in form factor. If your m.2 SSD is PCIe NVMe, then the story is different. It is much faster than SATA SSD, but the difference is not discernible to most users.

Is there any good deals for a 2-Bay NAS Backup and Home media sharing for my Smart TV to tap into this network drive to access to movies?
Get a Synology or QNAP and install Plex
You can also use your old PC or laptop and use the windows media player media sharing function to save cost.
Go with the Seagate IHM Promotion - DS216j + Seagate IronWolf It works perfectly in my home setup with Samsung smart TV. Dont know whether this round Seagate will still have the promotion or not....

There are a few distributor . Get pricing from both distributor and then compare. Go for Synology or Qnap. Both are reputable brands. For hard disk, you can consider getting Toshiba HDD from Sim Lim Square. Take a look at the Synology thread for more information.

I will recommend Asustor AS3102T ... similar spec as Synology 216+ and although there's slight diff in ram size but price quite a big difference. Asustor is a sub-brand from Asus. Basic media streaming is very stable (smooth never hang before) and files sharing via multi laptop is good as well. Majority will recommend Synology with WD RED HDD but I went for Asustor with HGST HDD and never regarded it so far. Most impt is the price if you're running on some budget. Lazada having sale soon with $100 off ... do your homework and hope you grab the best deal.

Very simple to handle this. First, there is zero ground for negotiation. Make the payment and pass the goods, since there is no agreement on the date and delivery of good. Second, ask for full refund, citing u need it immediately now and u are traveling tonight. U buy because u need it now. Third, call the credit card company to void the transaction citing fraud. Fourth, call the police on the spot citing a commercial fraud and hence a police report can be made for future reference in case you need further follow up with Case Trust. This will alone make the retailer alert up and willing to do something. Fifth, still make the Case Trust complain as a follow up to ensure they are being followed up by Case Trust.

Don't get TV Box in any electronic shows like this. Get it online no-frills.

In my opinion, rather than use android box, find that old/outdated laptop with HDMI output. Install Kodi OS onto it. (Less than 30 minutes by following youtube and online guides.) System requirement is like Raspberry Pi. Almost any laptop with HDMI can beat it. Input response seems to be much better than any other media system I tried so far. Plays almost all formats that I've thrown at it. For remote control, use Android/iPhone can download an app to sync with the PC through home network. Takes like less than 30 seconds to configure the sync. Save some money buy something else!

Bit the bullet and bought the T700W Brother ink tank printer from the Brother booth and got a rotten set. When I first opened the box the smell of unpleasantness filled my room and there's like white dot specks all over in the box and the boxes that contained the ink bottles. NVM I can over look that and continue unpacking my 'new' printer. I open the scanner and theres a white speck inside the glass and 3/4 of the glass looked foggy. There's like a stain on the top of the glass, I say on its on the top cos it felt different from the 1/4 clear glass that felt smooth to the touch. That stain was unremovable. I am not sure how that stain got there or what made it. I have a feeling those white specks are mold. It's really disgusting to think about all those mold spores floating around my place now. I do hope I am wrong about them being mold. Anyway I quickly packed up that printer and it's now sitting near the main door. Troublesome sia, need to lurge this heavy ass printer and go back to comex tml or best denki since they man this booth. I should have just went with the T500w online at qoo10. It was just $232 after $50 and store coupon and also includes delivery.

It's not all roses for OLED displays. Pure screen performance and black levels, yes. They do have a few downsides for which Samsung doesn't face since it's not using an OLED panel. And it can withstand a bright room a lot better than an OLED display (though the latter is improving too). But other than the above, Both are very good TVs as a whole. Beyond pure panel performance, one should also take into consideration of other features and design considerations. It basically boils down to what aspect a buyer values most given the usage scenario. While I agree that LG's OLED TVs are the performance leader from a performance perspective (our own reviews say so), what I want to clarify is your sentence of being hoodwinked on the Samsung QLED TVs isn't accurate. shadowoflight wrote: I'm glad people are not being hoodwinked into getting samsung's Q'LCDs'.

First 'hoodwink' - LED TVs have better picture quality because it's an LED display. Most of the public think that they're looking at LED panels, and by extension, that the 'LED Panels' are what's giving them improved display quality. Obviously that's not the case, because only the backlight changed to LED from CCFL aka fluorescent tubes. Practically no difference in picture quality. LED TVs are still LCD TVs. With a different bulb. And Samsung made a killing because it's basically the old LCD tech with a different price charged at a premium because the lay-consumer thought that it was a new type of screen. Second 'hoodwink' - QLED. This builds on the first misconception, and so lay-consumers would think that of these are Quantum Dot LED Displays. As we all know now, and thanks to more detailed and accurate reporting by most tech news sources now, we know that 'QLED' is actually LCDs + a QD filter. From here, we'll also know that this is a much, much cheaper tech than OLED. And yet they tried to charge more for their QLCDs. Basically, what Samsung tried to do with their QD tech is to pull another 'LED TV' marketing farce. But like they've failed, because when OLED became mainstream, people understood the difference between these panels, and when QLED launched, people actively tried to understand how it worked as opposed to taking it at face value, and were educated about the difference, as we can tell from Samsung's inability to charge the QLCD screens at a higher price than OLED displays. Your counter argument is valid - only from the perspective of a person who understands objectively the pros and cons of the different tech, i.e. you. My focus, is on public perception, who are not as informed, and Samsung is a master at playing the fiddle. Dr.Vijay wrote: It's not all roses for OLED displays. Pure screen performance and black levels, yes. They do have a few downsides for which Samsung doesn't face since it's not using an OLED panel. And it can withstand a bright room a lot better than an OLED display (though the latter is improving too). But other than the above, Both are very good TVs as a whole. Beyond pure panel performance, one should also take into consideration of other features and design considerations. It basically boils down to what aspect a buyer values most given the usage scenario. While I agree that LG's OLED TVs are the performance leader from a performance perspective (our own reviews say so), what I want to clarify is your sentence of being hoodwinked on the Samsung QLED TVs isn't accurate.

From certain viewpoints, yes, it's a marketing game. However, IMHO, we can only say one has been hoodwinked when for example one is getting something worse off at the same price. Where they stand now, they are offering a good alternative to OLED TVs - and not just in TV panel tech, but as a whole package. They are also not charging more as you've rightly pointed too. So at the end of the day, it depends which marketing wowed you more / which salesman did a better job / what one is personally inclined towards. It's business as usual. At the end of the day, the onus is upon consumers who have specific needs or expecting something specific to do their own homework. Else, the decision driver will flow towards which brand does a better job at marketing. For example, OLED TVs are fantastic in image quality, but frankly, LG's TVs are designed to wow rather than designed to inspire quality. They are rather fragile and those with kids, the TV better be out of reach for them. On the other hand Samsung does a great job in PQ generally (if you're not exactly comparing against an OLED), but the build quality is much better and more reassuring thanks to a more conventional design.  Same goes for the Sony equivalents too. That's not to say we won't recommend LG TVs - it's still the winner of 2016 and 2017 TVs by our books as we place a high emphasis on overall TV performance. However the recommendation based on pure performance isn't the first priority for everyone; when you're not doing a head-to-head comparison, at any given price point, most TVs look great on their own and they will certainly be many times better than what most people are upgrading from. As such, performance may not be the differentiating factor; features, design and price play a higher role for the average consumer. But as far as getting your hands on the best new tech for the same price, then yes, what you say holds true if nothing else is added to the equation. shadowoflight wrote: First 'hoodwink' - LED TVs have better picture quality because it's an LED display. Most of the public think that they're looking at LED panels, and by extension, that the 'LED Panels' are what's giving them improved display quality. Obviously that's not the case, because only the backlight changed to LED from CCFL aka fluorescent tubes. Practically no difference in picture quality. LED TVs are still LCD TVs. With a different bulb. And Samsung made a killing because it's basically the old LCD tech with a different price charged at a premium because the lay-consumer thought that it was a new type of screen. Second 'hoodwink' - QLED. This builds on the first misconception, and so lay-consumers would think that of these are Quantum Dot LED Displays. As we all know now, and thanks to more detailed and accurate reporting by most tech news sources now, we know that 'QLED' is actually LCDs + a QD filter. From here, we'll also know that this is a much, much cheaper tech than OLED. And yet they tried to charge more for their QLCDs. Basically, what Samsung tried to do with their QD tech is to pull another 'LED TV' marketing farce. But like they've failed, because when OLED became mainstream, people understood the difference between these panels, and when QLED launched, people actively tried to understand how it worked as opposed to taking it at face value, and were educated about the difference, as we can tell from Samsung's inability to charge the QLCD screens at a higher price than OLED displays. Your counter argument is valid - only from the perspective of a person who understands objectively the pros and cons of the different tech, i.e. you. My focus, is on public perception, who are not as informed, and Samsung is a master at playing the fiddle.

I bought the 65KS7500. Went to PC Show @ MBS first then to CEE to compare. Basically their free gifts are slightly different and they are not aware of what each other is offering. Not many sets left and I was told by Friday night should be out of stock already. If I recall correctly, below are the things offered. I went with CEE pricing - got them to match PC Show price. PC Show (Courts Booth) Price: $4599 Free 48" TV, Samsung sound bar, Samsung wireless keyboard, slim wall mount, $100 grocery vouchers, xBox (Not sure which model). CEE (Best Denki) Price: $4299 (was $4599 but they match PC Show price for me) Free 48" TV, Samsung sound bar, Samsung wireless keyboard, slim wall mount, $100 grocery vouchers. As you can probably see, CEE didn't give xBox. Not that I mind though. I just want cash deduction. Managed to get $300 off to $4299. The take in price for the TV is $550, so you can opt for this to save some $$. If you sell off the free TV, soundbar and wall mount, should be able to recoup about $800. That makes the TV @ $3500. Pretty damn good deal.

Yes, the little red dot has 5 telecommunication carriers. As a customer myself, sometimes I do find things very fluff and confusing, especially with all the jargon and superfluous numbers being thrown all around. Don\u2019t worry, I am here to simplify all that for you, so you don\u2019t end up signing a 2-year contract full of regret. \u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014 MOBILE First, let\u2019s take a look at the buffet offered to you. Note that I have chosen the \u201c2nd-tier\u201d plan as that\u2019s the most \u201cgeneral\u201d plan for most people. [IMG]https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1800/1*B0R9dRev-G5XY8KWBV4Pbw.png[/IMG] As you can see, there isn\u2019t much \u201cdifferentiation\u201d between the Big 3\u2026 The only thing that stands out is that SingTel offers 1GB less than that of others. WIN: M1. But wait, what if you are a student? [IMG]https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1800/1*8q9P9JSvu23qERo2ULlf-A.png[/IMG] Without a shadow of a doubt, StarHub offers the best value for money. WIN: StarHub. Now here\u2019s the category where things get contentious. [IMG]https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1800/1*_x3z79IufdjWgpRqf4VasA.png[/IMG] Across the 4, all look pretty decent, except for SingTel. StarHub just loses out to M1 by a hair. Between M1 and Circles, M1 appears to have better value. WIN: M1? Nope. Circles.Life because 20for20 is just too good. Overall, if you\u2019re on a contract, StarHub is the best choice. If you\u2019re not, then Circles.Life is the obvious choice. \u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014\u200a\u2014 FIBRE The same goes for broadband. I\u2019m choosing the most \u201cgeneral\u201d plan, the one that offers 1Gbps. [IMG]https://cdn-images-1.medium.com/max/1800/1*EMdvyctfmnf1UXH8ZE26JQ.png[/IMG] Across them all, M1 is the cheapest, but SingTel offers great value despite its higher price. Still, so long as you don\u2019t choose MyRepublic, you\u2019re good to go. WIN: SingTel. Overall, there doesn\u2019t seem to be much competition with regards to the fibre game. With that said, if you and your family have a bundle package (i.e. mobile + fibre + TV), that\u2019s the best choice to settle for at the moment. You\u2019re NOT going to be better off by mixing and matching the best of each category. Figures correct as of 22 July 2017

TS is very BIASED in the report. I have used Singtel and M1 simultaneously. M1 firstly has awful phone pricing when buying with contract. Sometimes even $50 more expensive than other other telcos. Then when it comes to phone trade-ins, the price of the phone a lot lower than what other telcos also offer. So in the end, you end up paying $100 more than with other telcos. I ended up changing my second line back to Singtel afterwards. Best trade-in prices most of the time and the price for when you use services like Samsung Concierge, you can see the amount they'll pay for when you want to re-contract every year means you won't even have to pay the penalty for early recontract at all. So just concentrate on paying for the phone itself. No experience with Starhub anymore. So I won't comment on them. As for FIBRE, never ever take Starhub as they do not care about gamers. Their DNS routing is so bad that while players on Singtel, ViewQwest and MyRepublic are on 50-59ms, Starhub players were getting 130+ms ping on Blizzard servers. So we should treat Starhub the same way they treat their customers. Avoid completely.

You are judging too early, PC Show is in June. Amazon is worth it due to price change and free shipping for some items. Some new release items like 1080ti are being sold by scalpers at US$200 mark up. So it's cheaper to buy locally. I have bought a lot of items from Amazon and some items are worth it even if you RMA once. But twice would not have been worth it, e.g. I recently RMA Corsair H75, shipping was about $40. Pros is I can do this on a weekend and they mail back to my doorstep. Cons is if I send it in one more time, it would have been more expensive than local. Other things to consider is a transformer due to the difference in voltage. A good one doesn't come cheap as well. So for anyone buying computer stuff, do take note, sharing my experience here. For other household items like kitchen stuff like Joseph and Simple Human, it's cheaper there and lower risk of failure compared to electronics.

Just yesterday, I visited the annual IT EXPO as I planned to get an older Windows 7 base laptop which was advertised in a leaflet. I visited the booth, I asked for the laptop and a sale personnel presented to me a $399 forth generation i5 HP Windows 7 laptop with 1 year OEM warranty which they did not have sample of because he said its limited stock daily in the show. I decided to buy it though. When I was about to make the payment, a staff behind the counter told me this is the last one for the day and the package was opened only for the purpose of the customer to take a look at the color and he promised its a brand new unit. As I was in a rush, I just made a minor inspection for any visible damages then I bought it. Then later I tried to mess with the newly bought laptop. I saw plenty of chinese characters in an english environment setup. To my surprised its an i5 but M520 chipset, a first generation i series not the forth as promised! I realize it was running on Windows 7 Ultimate version! Its only then I realize something was seriously wrong because its not possible that OEM will include the Ultimate license for that laptop's configuration, its simply under power. So I look around the laptop for the Windows license sticker which must be visible usually at the bottom of the unit. Not to my surpised, its nowhere to be found. Its not a genuine Windows 7. The worse part is yet to be over. When I took a closer look at the HP logo under the display, I realize the printing looks uneven! Then I close up the lip, guess what? The circular HP logo which was unique to pavilion series fell off from its sticky tape! My closer inspection concluded that it was not an authentic HP product as the plastic feels cheap and none of those HP labels could found on the unit. You can imagine how I felt, so I went right back to the show and ask for refund. They agreed to refund me like immediately. They are basically telling me they know they're selling counterfeit HP product by doing so. I checked, the company of that booth is Atrix Dynamics Pte Ltd, the main store is located at Sim Lim Square level 6. This was my first experienced for being scammed in a trade show and hopefully the last.

THIS IS NOT APRIL FOOL TRICK!! I hope any thinking of getting a laptop from the show will read these and think twice. Who knows, you may also unknowingly buy a second handed or with some expensive parts swop out.

Even told them I registered online and why the warranty period was March instead of April and was told that online registration is only for 'self' purposes and not with them. (Is this a sick joke? Why would I even bother registering online then?!) Boycott ASUS by all means man.... What a scam of my money be it pertaining to the wifi card or warranty duration. If you have the invoice, just go and claim the warranty with your invoice. They recognize invoice only. Registration online does not mean anything. One can buy in Jan, then register in 5 months later in June. Thus online registration by most brands does not count. The warranty date now follows your manufacture date, which is 1 month earlier than your purchase. When you send down the first time for servicing, you probably did not bring in your invoice, thus they are unable to update the system. This is rather standard warranty policy across most brands.
That\u2019s why never buy in local shop
MoyoCase wrote: That\x92s why never buy in local shop Not all local shops are bad. Not web purchase are happy ending anyway.

All if not most of electronic products, unless you can produce the invoice, otherwise will be based on manufacture date. If you exceed 10GB at any  time on a Saturday or Sunday, we will impose a speed limit of 1 Mbps.  The speed limit will be lifted on the following day. StarHub reserves the right to amend the fair usage cap and speed  limit from time to time at its discretion without any prior notice.

As title, want switch fibre bb from Green to Orange. but after contact the hot line, realise I need to terminate first, then old isp can release fibre port to allow new isp to use, and it will take some time. how you manage the internet down time?

HoGnix wrote: As title, want switch fibre bb from Green to Orange. but after contact the hot line, realise I need to terminate first, then old isp can release fibre port to allow new isp to use, and it will take some time. how you manage the internet down time? the fibre point should have 2 ports, one currently used by ur green. The other telco can simply come install in the unused one. Dont have to terminate first before installing new one.
Did you have a different ISP prior to using SH? That ISP didn't release your fibre port?
For info,SH is the first and only fibre isp.So, it is safe to say I can get Orange bb online before terminate Green. Thanks.

In that case, your scenario is quite similar to mine. I also moved from green to orange back in Feb. Don't terminate your SH yet. Signup for M1 first. Once you get the M1 ONT installed and confirmed internet is working, then you can bring your SH ONT to one of the service centres to terminate it (have to bring along power adapter, the yellow fibre cable, and the LAN cable that comes with the ONT).  Cannot call to terminate, have to terminate by returning to the service centre. If you are porting over your digital voice to M1, then don't terminate SH first.  Wait for 5 working days after M1 ONT installed until your current number works on the M1 ONT, then you can terminate SH.

Got clear picture, thanks a lot. Ah-Pin-Kor wrote: In that case, your scenario is quite similar to mine. I also moved from green to orange back in Feb. Don't terminate your SH yet. Signup for M1 first. Once you get the M1 ONT installed and confirmed internet is working, then you can bring your SH ONT to one of the service centres to terminate it (have to bring along power adapter, the yellow fibre cable, and the LAN cable that comes with the ONT).  Cannot call to terminate, have to terminate by returning to the service centre. If you are porting over your digital voice to M1, then don't terminate SH first.  Wait for 5 working days after M1 ONT installed until your current number works on the M1 ONT, then you can terminate SH.

Desolator wrote: I'm currently on Singtel ADSL 15mbps plan and I wish to jump to M1 fibre 500mbps. If I sign up at sitex show, can they waived off the one-time registration fee? I don't think it's possible. Nobody got it waived off. It's the charge by NetLink Trust, not M1. But then, since you're on SingNet ADSL, you can opt for the 1Gbps @ $34/mth (12 months $29 + 12 months $39). Inclusive of the router, which is what the 500Mbps + router costs. Still need to pay the registration fee of $48.15, but you technically get free speed boost. Or just pay $31/mth inclusive of router for 300Mbps Fibre on the same promotion. Maybe you can ask them for the 500Mbps upgrade but I'm not sure if allowed or not. https://www.m1.com.sg/personal/bundles%20and%20promotions/highlights/fbb-switch The reason why I'm including router costs is because SingNet routers are not compatible with other ISPs at all, plus ADSL routers use such old tech that you can't even get speeds close too.

jaxel80 wrote: Actually the ont termination pt also netlink charge de, then y tat one can waive off??? So if my hse the ont termination pt aldy done then can waive off the registration fee???? No, ONT installation charge is actually done by M1, that's why can waive. Activation charge is by Netlink Trust, to hook up the Fibre connection. TP is the Termination Point. That's installed by Netlink Trust, formerly known as OpenNet, mostly for free in the past. If you have to install now, it cost $235.40 for HDB flats, much higher for landed property.

razorlala wrote: Roadshow is $29 for 300mbps? Hopefully $29 for 500 Mbps pop up again.

There is a difference between throughput and bandwidth. Every server has a fixed speed per connection. Unless you using many different services, each person typically wont use beyond 20mbps. 500mbps is more than sufficient for like ~20 devices. Even more so if throttling by the isp is involved.

razorlala wrote: There is a difference between throughput and bandwidth. Every server has a fixed speed per connection. Unless you using many different services, each person typically wont use beyond 20mbps. 500mbps is more than sufficient for like ~20 devices. Even more so if throttling by the isp is involved. Each server has their own control over how fast one can download and upload.  The server must control the internet traffic.

dryteletubby wrote: WiFi speed primally depends on you devices and interference. And due to regulations, all routers will have the same maximum output and range. Mesh can help with range but a wired AP will be better than mesh if you have or are able to run cables For a wired AP or wireless AP, would the SSID be the same or different ?

csc12345678 wrote: For a wired AP or wireless AP, would the SSID be the same or different ? Set it the same so your devices can choose which signal to lock on to itself. You have to balance the singnal output to ensure WiFi broadcast does not overlap too much resulting in your devices not be able to choose which ap to connect to.

You will still have to continue using your old ONT To protect yourself take a screen shot of the promotion and video the whole process of application In the case for Starhub, the 6 months free can come in a few forms. 1) It is either, you pay for 9 months for 1st year and then 3 months, no need to pay and the same goes for 2nd year. 2) Or you pay for 18 months. And then, the last 6 months will be free. This is because, they will not happily hand you over the free 6 months if you have not shown that you can pay your bills properly so to protect the organisation, the free stuffs will only be received towards the end. 3) the 6 months free minus-ed away from the total amount for 24 months and then you'll end up paying like $39 per month for 24 months for a $49 per month plan. Just a marketing strategy to make it look like you are receiving a discount when they intended to sell their plan at $39 per month to begin with.

troublesome58 wrote: Consider Dell S2718H? It is supposed to be 4k according to brochure. Looks damn cheap! The S2718H/S2718HX model is Full HD, not UHD (or 4K) as the brochure has listed. I was discussing this with my friend yesterday and, it's just not possible for a UHD (or 4K monitor) with IPS screen to be priced so low. You can't find much information about this model on the internet as it is still relatively new, but you will be able to find its user manual. In the manual, it states that the PPI is 81. For a 27" 4K monitor, the PPI should be 163, whereas a 27" 1080p monitor has a PPI of 81. I don't know why they put the UHD resolution in the brochure, maybe the monitor is able to accept the UHD resolution with a HDMI 2.0 cable, then supersample/downsample down to the full HD (1080p) resolution. Just for comparison sake, an LG 27" UHD IPS monitor costs >800SGD, whereas a Dell 27" UHD TN monitor costs >700SGD. If I am wrong, do let me know.. As I won't mind buying another 27" UHD monitor at that price..

troublesome58 wrote: But if you look at page 12 of the manual, it also says it is 4k.. But our discussion is just academic if it is not for sale. Yup, we will know the true specs when the monitor is officially released. Not to say that you are wrong, but I stand by my understanding that the S2718H/S2718HX monitor is physically a Full HD monitor that somehow accepts a UHD input (4K) through a HDMI 2.0 cable. I do hope that I am wrong, because that would be a really cheap price for a 4K monitor. The reason why I say that it's a Full HD monitor is simple. 1. Price - My current LG 27UD88 4K monitor costs $865. The similarly specced 27" Dell IPS 4K monitor also cost around $849. Therefore, this led to my doubt about the $359 S2718H monitor being a full 4K monitor. 2. The manual listed that the Pixel Per Inch (PPI) of the S2718H monitor is 81. A true 27" 4K monitor would have PPI of 163, whereas a true 27" Full HD monitor would have a PPI of 81. This would suggest that the S2718H is physically a Full HD monitor. 3. The monitor would accept a 4K input only under special circumstances, that is OSD Movie HDR or Game HDR. To be honest, I have no idea what is Movie HDR or Game HDR, but under normal windows settings, the maximum resolution is 1920 x 1080 as listed in the manual. TL;DR Price is too low, PPI is too low to be a real 4K monitor. Of course, I hope to be proven wrong. This is all my humble opinions. My advise is to wait for the monitor to come out before deciding to drop the money on it. There are also a few threads on other forums debating about this, like here and here , if anyone is interested.

The supplied hdmi should be 2.0, When you install the driver you should be able to see the monitor detected with a 2.0 cable. However 4k can only be achieved in the movie  HDR or games HDR modes.. please correct if I'm wrong

I have not tried the supplied cables.. Actually, those that advertise the cable that is 4k (high speed hdmi with ethernet) is legit.. But bear in mind this is about 10.2 Gbps and it is rated as only HDMI 1.4. Max resolution is only at 30Hz.. I bought these supposed 4k HDMI cheap cables from Lazada advertised as HDMI 2.0 but in fact it is only rated at HDMI 1.4b. I suggest you to specifically buy the HDMI 2.0 in stores such as Challenger, Best.. etc. Choose the 18Gbps. These cables are the ones that can do the 2160p@60Hz. If your resolution can do 2160p@60Hz or 3840 x 2160 @60Hz.. That is the true 4k.

There will be people from various monitor brands walking around IT show to distribute the flyers... normally they will have a human billboard behind their back as well .. be sure to look out for them .. if you still can't find then u can just walk around the perimeter of the area & look up at the billboard to find the brands of the monitor u desire ... If everything else fails just ask some1 walking by i'm sure they'll be glad to assist u

HDR is about contrast.. full 4k experience is if you combine contrast, chroma, resolution and frequency.. the more you achieve the qualities of the hdmi 2.0 standard, the better you achieve those requirement.. In our case, our Dell monitor has HDR.. As to why it supports HDR is to compensate on the lacking elements like nits and the bits.. this is to experience 4k with such a cheap price.. in my reading, 3 requirement is needed to combine in order to achieve this.. the content (game or video) needs to support.. the graphics card.. and the monitor.. our monitor has 2 hdr modes. Movie and game.. you need to select either of the 2.. after the windows creator update, if you toggle this, there seems to be an issue.. if you google this, it has something to do with gpu driver support..

Quote: There\u2019s no such thing as an HDMI 2.0/2.0a cable. More reading on this matter in our guide:- http://www.hardwarezone.com.sg/featu...mi-20-hevc-uhd You just need a good quality cable. The rest is marketing. yoyolamefan wrote: Have you tried? Does buying a HDMI 2.0 give u better resolution?

Dr.Vijay wrote: More reading on this matter in our guide:- http://www.hardwarezone.com.sg/featu...mi-20-hevc-uhd You just need a good quality cable. The rest is marketing. This is somewhat true. To be able to achieve HDR, the cable that you have matters. The one that has 18Gbps bandwidth will have the label; Certified Premium. That is when the cable is fully capable of transferring 18 Gbps. Here is the current scenario that I faced. Basically with my previous Certified Premium cable, I was able to activate HDR on the port (LG based UHDTV) which is then connected to my PC. Games like Mass Effect Andromeda works perfectly. But recently, due to my wallmounting, I needed a longer cable to reach my PC. So I bought another Certified Premium cable of the same brand. Due to it being bent a lot cos of the wall mount and having to go through the hole, the cable was not able to carry the full 18 Gbps bandwidth and that in itself has affected the HDR functionality even when it is not even turned on. Basically, my TV will flicker like crazy showing black screen and back to the screen and then black screen again even when I'm not watching any HDR content but am outputting at 4K. I had to lower the 4K display output to just 30Hz and not even 50Hz in order to not get the flicker. Today, my Port Saver came. So I was able to use the port saver to do the bend while my HDMI cable is not being bent as much. This resulted in a much more stable 4K 60Hz with Deep Colour enabled which is LG's term for allowing HDR content to be received on the port. Don't even try to use a HDMI 'High Speed' cable. Their bandwidth will not be stable enough to carry 4K 60Hz even. That is without even including HDR in the mix. Hope that helps. Anyway, not long, HDMI 2.1 ports will be available on new TVs and Graphic Cards and consoles and even new players. (Yes. You'll need new players and all for HDMI 2.1) With HDMI 2.1, the difference with HDMI 2.0 is so huge that it will be able to carry the full Chroma 4:4:4. That is why you see a sudden drought of 4K blu rays and even the upcoming monitors being delayed. As all are waiting for the HDMI 2.1 standard. Meaning again, new cables. But because of the ridiculously high bandwidth, I believe even with the cable bent, it should be able to carry the full bandwidth output. So look out for that!

Guys, would like to share my experience with this product n seller CH2. I bought a Red Bean i-flame tv box last night at the Comex 2017.  They were marketing on 2 of such products: i-flame n the other i-mini or somthing.  Claiming that i-flame is a newer model (2017) with better specs n nothing much were said about the i-mini (2016). The original price is varies from $359 to $259 and shop currently selling at $179.  As usual, the drama marketing scheme started selling at $159 for limited pcs n eventually dropped to $99. The board stated 3yrs warranty but the receipt only mentioned 1 yr warranty. When I clarified later, the seller explained that 3yrs warranty for software n 1 yr warranty is meant for the hardware. I tried connecting n setting it up last night but gave up eventually as it was so slow n lagging. Not giving up, I tried again this morning.  The streaming is extremely slow.  I thought it was my wifi reception is my room so I moved the set to the living, set it up right beside my router.  Now, I've dual band 1Gbps router n the i-flame can only detect 2.4Ghz bandwidth. The streaming still very slow n i decided to install n try out the speed test. The results was disappointing. I tried connecting varies wifi i.e. my router, my portable wifi router with 4G SIM n wifi hotspot from my mobiles.  The speed ranged from 1mbps to 10mbps only.  If you connect to LAN, the speed is still acceptable. So if you intend to connect via LAN, the product is ok. If wifi, you can forget about it.  Next I noticed, the box stated 8GB memory but the internal memory is only 2GB + internal SD storage 4GB. I went down to the shop at AMK Hub only to realise that several buyer were also complaining about the streaming speed. Then I noticed that they are selling at $100 n said its a low end model. I requested to exchange for other products for the amount I paid but was rejected. I proceed down to Comex again to demand for a refund. They just refund quietly. Oh boy, I looked at the number of people queuing for the product, a lot of people will definitely be very disappointed.

A lot of such Android TV box comes with very low end specs. The wifi is usually very slow because of the cheap hardware, and the LAN runs at 100Mbps instead of Gigabit LAN. Having said that, you don't need anything more than 20 to 30 Mbps to stream proper Full HD content. At 720p, the bandwidth requirement is even lower. Laggy playback is usually attributed to the servers which are typically based in China.
lol 300+ original price u belive meh

All these cheap Android boxes and the smart phones could come with malware apps. I used to buy cheap Lenovo Android phone for less than $100 at such event @Expo and later found out few default apps are malware when using company enterprise malware tool to scan it. They will still be there even with factory reset due to default apps. Imagine having these potentially malicious boxes connected to your home wifi which can reach the rest of your home gadgets and probably detecting all your home wifi activities. Better to get from reputable brand AND seller if really need to have one. My 2 cents.

buzzmario wrote: check with you, my company allow for home use program but it is via office email. but office email only access via office pc, so how the purchase like to be take place? You put your office email in, it sends you a code (which you will receive at work unless your work email server blocks inbound messages from external servers), and then you enter that code into the HUP website from home when you want to make the purchase.

It's worth asking (for Op) whether they even need MS Office or could survive with one of the various alternatives which are free whether it be Google Docs (online based) or OpenOffice. Office 365 is great if you're going to make use of the cloud features like 1TB OneDrive, full access to mobile apps on iPad/iPhone, Skype international credit, etc... and buying the one year home subscription (for 5 PCs + 5 tablets/phones + 5 MS accounts) is actually decent value especially if you buy it when it's on offer pricing. Otherwise, traditional Office is great but only if you need full functionality. It isn't cheap though unless you're eligible for either HUP or at least student edition.

I'm not sure whether its better to get online or onsite. but IMHO, the deal not good leh. You are basically paying for the PS4 in 24month installment. Current IT Show promo  : Normal 1Gbps plan : $49.99 x 24 months = 1199.76 - (4 months free x $49.99) = $999.8 - $250 router discount = $749.8. PS4 Pro 1Gbps plan : $74.99 x 24 months = $1799.76 - $70 (router discount) = $1,729.76 - $599 (PS4 pro price) = $1,130.76 Is $380.96 difference. $75 vs $50 = $25 difference per month x 24 months = $600 (the price of the PS4 pro). plus, they only give you $70 router discount, compared to $250 discount on normal plan. PLUS, normal plan you get 4 months free.

Never, ever buy power line adapters.  That rubbish barely gives a decent connection, and is unstable as hell.  Drops all the time.  It's just some hobo technology to make users believe they can get wired connection without laying lines. For $150 (cost of the adapter), you can get any contractor to come your house and lay Cat 6 cables.  Gold standard, not that expensive, do once and forget.  This is from my own experience with trying different adapters before caving in to what I should have done from the start.

Based on my experience, I find that if your current wireless router is high-end, then getting a good extender will achieve much higher speed than with homeplug. I agree that for homeplug, TP-Link is quite impressive. I am also using TL-WPA8730 for many months. Before that, I was using Aztech 500Mbps, but it only give me 80Mbps, which I accepted it as a way of life due to my old condo wiring. Then last year, I tested the TP-Link TL-WPA8730, which achieved about 200Mbps when plugged directly to wall socket (even though the app claims I get full 1200Mbps throughput). Unfortunately, my study room no space to plug the homeplug directly, so I had to plug to extension cord, and I ended up getting 120Mbps, which is not too bad (the app shows throughput drops to 230Mbps). Good thing is that this model also has a wireless extender which I also utilise. Recently, I received a review unit from D-Link DAP-1720. After 2 weeks of testing, I am pleased with the performance. This extender comes with LAN port so I plugged the desktop directly to DAP-1720 instead of WPA8730 and I attained above 300Mbps. Very happy. In addition, I felt that the DAP-1720 extender works better than the WPA8730 extender, in terms of speed as well as coverage. So end of the day, it depends on your house layout. Homeplug has an uncertainty that the existing wires are not optimised, and requires direct wall socket, whereas wireless extender is more flexible, easier to deploy. Disclaimer: D-Link and TP-Link products are on long-term loan to me as a product reviewer-blogger. I share my experience and I use these products for months. I am not paid to write for any brands, so hope you appreciate my sharing of my experience here. If you want to read my reviews in details, you can visit my blog and read further on each of the above products. Reference links: TP-Link TL-WPA8730 AV1200 D-Link DAP-1720 AC1750 D-Link DAP-1860 AC2600

Edit, 19 Mar Sunday, 4.27pm: Deepest apologies on my part as I got the name of the store wrong. The store is actually called X-Kimi (6485). Modern tech is selling TV boxes and uninvolved in the deal. I did get a due refund in the end though fake MI most likely still being sold. For latest update, please read my post on page 4 or click this link . I was at IT Show earlier (18 Mar, Sat) and became an unsuspecting victim of a counterfeit Mi Power Bank scam. I was unaware before this incident that there were so many shady deals happening at these events. The store in question is called Modern Tech (Booth 6347) X-Kimi (6485), situated at level 6, right across the Seagate booth. The salesmen looked like a bunch of Singaporean guys and they were selling mi powerbank 10400mah at $15 among other miscellaneous products like wireless keyboards, mouse and the like. Frontal photo of booth (taken on 19 Mar, Sunday) As the owner of an authentic mi powerbank (that I received as a gift), I thought $15 was a pretty good deal since the retail price of a regular mi 10400mah powerbank was $26. Along with a middle-aged lady and some Bangladesh workers, I bought myself one silver powerbank. If I remembered correctly, the sign above the powerbanks even said 'Genuine Mi Powerbanks', I should have known better, sigh. After buying the product, back at home, I began to test it out. The first thing I realised is the usb cable provided cannot even fit into the port. None of my own personal cables fit into the powerbank as well. The charger simply put, did not work. This got me suspicious and I took out my old powerbank to compare with the one I just bought. A quick search online also showed me how to identify a fake powerbank ( x ). As I guessed, I had been duped, the powerbank is a fake product. These are the results of my findings. All of the pictures here belong to me. And apparently, these same sellers are scamming people on Lazada as well. I reported this matter to the IT Show Organisers on Facebook though it looks like nothing can be done till the show is over. Once they reply, I will update this thread accordingly. A google search online also showed me this was not the first time that this had happened. http://forums.hardwarezone.com.sg/si...s-4892255.html http://forums.hardwarezone.com.sg/co...k-5162882.html http://forums.hardwarezone.com.sg/ce...h-5065123.html https://www.allsingaporestuff.com/ar...-illegal-spore Quite honestly, I am to blame too for being greedy and uninformed. I will go back to the booth tomorrow and try asking for a refund, but otherwise, I will take this $15 as a lesson learned. However, even with that said, just because incidents like this had happened so frequently, I do not think the IT fair and other such events should condone such behaviour. Doing so only ruins the experience for everyone who is there to have a good time. I also feel bad for those Bangladesh workers who were there before me. It pains me to think about how many hours they have to work to gain back the same sum of money. TLDR; Everyone please be vigilant before buying anything at the IT Fair and other subsequent shows. If the deal seems too good to be true, exercise caution before forking out your money. Also, just avoid Modern Tech X-Kimi (6485) at all costs.

Sunday Update: MI can take no action, shamed the wrong shop (it's actually x-kimi), contacted organisers, got a refund from store owner, fake xiaomi most likely still being sold I went back to Suntec today to find the sellers today. But before coming up to the convention centre, I made a stop at the MI Shop at level 2 first. Salesperson there confirmed item is fake but said nothing much can be done on their part as this problem had been persisting for a long time. They told me I could try emailing their customer service but legal action is unlikely and even if there is, it's going to be a long arduous process. I went to level 6 to take pictures to verify where I made the purchase. Sellers still selling xiaomi powerbanks, this time at $16. Perhaps their sales were too good, the amount of powerbanks they have was nearly halved of what I saw yesterday. I went to the IT Show organisers' office on level 4 and this time they took action. They verified where I made the purchase from and realise that the store is actually called X-kimi. My deepest apologies to Modern tech, that are simply selling 3rd party android TV boxes. The it show  representative contacted the boss of x-kimi and we went back to the booth upstairs. I was introduced to the boss of x-kimi that as it turned out was a prc. Once we reached the store, I realised they are selling the powerbanks at $15 again.  He claimed that their MI powerbanks are imported and authentic but fakes might have been mixed into his stocks. I showed him the proof of his products being fake, he said it was just a one time mistake. The shop refunded me the $15 and they sent me on my way. I got my money back but sellers are still selling these powerbanks when I was leaving. So to all remaining it show goers, please take note. Here are some review which I bought the $299 package. Today juz have the time to test out the add-on apps n iptv. Had a few hiccups with login licensing into the box.. entered the code, prompt me error.. -_-" .. as it was midnite 12 plus since they mentioned 24/7 support.. I have forgotten to ask what was the support contact numbers.. the only way is receipt contact numbers.. tried calling to a HP numbers.. a lady pick up the phone.. might be the Taiwan lady boss.. I explained my problems with her and she give my ways to troubleshoot by off and on back the box.. miracle.. iptv was login in without keying the codes again.. With iptv, almost all of the channels are working except 1 or 2 uncommon channels.. mainly all channels works fine and best of all the suppose to be English channels are English example Disney junior, Cartoon Network.. Unlike HDTV or Huat88tv if u know wat I mean.. Met an issue todae are, when a few hrs (2-3) of iptv watched.. my channel suddenly becomes blackout and I tried to switch channels.. still black out.. closing the apps and relaunching will not help.. unless I switch off n on the minix.. n tats the only problem I faced till now.. Anyone got this problem? For the built in apps.. common apps were installed by them, like cartoon hd, megabox, rss channels, \u5343\u5bfb, terrarium tv, blank Kodi..all working fine. As I tried to view a movie from cartoon hd..and launched MX player for viewing.. notice I can't search for subtitles as it was unable to select the search buttons in MX.. anyone can teach me? But with terrarium tv.. I was able to search subtitles using MX players search engine..dunno y.. Overall, I could say I'm happy with minix compare with my old Mibox.. and $299 for box and 4 yrs iptv subscription should be worth it.. the lady boss was kind to answer my calls last midnite when I faced problem login into iptv..

I intend to get a colour printer to supplement my current laser AIO printer. Anyone has a set, what are your comment on printing quality and copying quality?  Would the printer has any paper loading problem? Print head... Any other suggestion. Tight budget below $200, low print volume.

Mine's the older model Epson L350 Ink Tank. Print volume is low.  Can be 1 or 2 months between printing. For my printing cycle,  the printhead gets clogged easily. Repeated cleaning will unclog the printhead. However, within the warranty,  the printhead got clogged so badly that cleaning doesn't help.  It was changed under warranty. IMHO,  likely it could be the ink technology used for my model.  Not sure if there are any change to the L360. To prevent clogging,  use it every 1 or 2 weeks.   It's a hassle. The plus points -  the ink last a long time. I am waiting for the ink to run out and try Canon. I have very good experience with Canon non-ink tank model.  Use once every six months also not an issue.   The rare occurrence of clogging,  cleaning will eliminate it. I usually don't go for Epson and HP.  But no choice for the L350,  the only one in the market at that time. HTH. P.S.  Here's a tip - The fastest way to use the printer is the copy function.  On printer, load paper and "Copy' a few pieces. Tip #2 -  To eliminate paper jam,  use 80gsm and load what is necessary.  When the pack is opened, keep in ziplock bag.
Thank you Keenklee. Comprehensive comment and advice, appreciated. I did use canon printer previously, low end model, had a bad experience, that's why I change to laser printer. Anyway, thank you!

i will give my 2 cents thought on this, there's a few factors you might want to look into before committing into a gaming labtop.First, you want to look at the processor speed, most optimal now for most games would be around 2.4GHz to 3.4GHz,because it will give u the ease of having the smoothest gameplay along with multi tasking as well. So with that being said an Core i7 processor would suffice. Secondly, try to make sure the RAM is 8GB to 12 GB. This is to make sure your processor can take the strain on bigger games like the recent MMORPG Revelation Online etc. Lastly,go for a good graphics card that is set at 1920x1080 pixel screen for the best experience. Dosen't matter if it's GeForce or AMD. Alot of gaming labtops with these features actually goes for under $1500, so u can slowly take your time to look around & also choose the design of the labtop you like ! Also not to forget to get 1 with Lithium Ion Battery.

Hi ! I thought when the router could serve as a NAS, the NAS market would close down.  But not so.  So why is a NAS still necessary ? What do you prefer ? My router USB broke and my NAS also broke.  So I either buy a new router or a new NAS.   Any suggestions please. Thanks a lot for your inputs.

USB attached to a router has its limitations. Disk size, Raid support, speed & software functionality are a few of such limitations. If you want to store something for a longer term or not want to loose data, go for a NAS solution. If you want just a basic place to dump your movies, you can stick to the USB method
