AshSim wrote: Saw from news D-Link got the best IP Cam brand award by HWZ and best wireless router by The Straits Times. If I remember correctly, they didn't state which model.... Can you confirm? AshSim wrote: Based on Sitex, I don't think DCS-2630 will go under $200 but DCS-960L is under $200... how ah? The pricing from the last fair was as follows; http://www.hardwarezone.com.sg/itsho...chures/d-link/ The two new models launched since, the DCS 936L and 2530L, have yet to release their pricing for the fair. That said, I can help you with the following DCS 2630L - Wifi AC - 1080P - 180deg view angle DCS   960L - Wifi AC -  760P -  180deg view angle DCS   935L - Wifi AC -  760P - (H) 78.44\xb0 (V) 47.90\xb0 (D) 85.98\xb0 DCS   936L - Wifi N - (H) 100\xb0 (V) 54\xb0 (D) 120\xb0 DCS 2530L - Wifi N - 1080P - 180deg view angle, (Max 15fps) I cut and pasted from sites, and reflects my experience. To me the above is the post impt factors for the cameras, while balancing price. For me, especially for WIFI based cameras, was.... a. Do I want Wireless N or Wireless AC Its not a question of which is better or which is technically a necessity. For me, it was simply, there was too much congestion on the 2.4Ghz band in my area for me to want to try. So I chose Wifi AC. b. Resolution I knew, the bare minimum was 720P for me. A lot brands still offer 640P, claiming that it is sufficient for home use. I do partially agree. But what I did was google comparison videos and pictures of 1080P vs 720P vs 640P, and decide from there, Of course, price taken into consideration. c. Viewing Angle This should be something to consider when buying the camera. Basically the wider the angles the more you see. Some manufacturers will say, use a PTZ design. This is fine, but trust me, if you access your cameras often enough, moving the darn thing around is more like a good idea in theory than in reality, especially if you do it all the time. Finally, you should give some thought to a. How do you want to record? To SD card, to cloud, to NAS, to stand alone PC. All have their pros and cons. Cost in increasing order. b. How often will you be accessing recording? Once again, the listing in pt a, but in the reverse order.Stand alone PC easiest IMHO, NAS etc etc etc b. The more resolution you have, the more fps you have, the bigger your files will be. The bigger your files are, the shorter you can record on SD cards. etc etc etc. So its a case of plan what you want to achieve and how.... then list your camera models. Doesn't mean buy more expensive is better. Because to maximize it, you will have to outlay more. FYI, I use 6 cameras currently; 5 Dlinks, of which one is LAN Cable. Like you, I went with DLink at that time, because I wanted to be sure it would integrate easily with my router, DIR 868L. Last advise I can give you is, LAN cable connections is better than Wifi. And yes, DLink is a "pricier" brand for cameras.... Hope this helps.

hi all, thanks for all the comments and recommendations! u guys are really very helpful! tbh, I have been looking at a couple of brands including some china unknown brands... cheap as they may be... and perhaps it's only me, I do not really feel comfy buying them. anyway, in the end I grab 2 cams from the IT show and it's still cheaper than DIIR-895L! I got DCS-2630L for my living room and DCS-936L for my kitchen! So far working really good... I love DCS-2630L because it's 180-degree and I see everything from wall to wall. The camera is installed near my house's altar, facing the main door and at the same time, can check out 3 bedroom doors. DCS-936L is cheap and good! Somemore so small in size, it's easy to place it... although it's not 180-degree... my kitchen is longish, so placing it near the entrance will be able to capture most of the activities in the kitchen, including watching over my aged parents when they go to washroom and catching my dog if he decides to be naughty and pee on the rug. Have caught him twice after installing the IP cam for peeing on the rug (I got 2 dogs, so with this, I know who the culprit is). I hope in long run, these 2 wont give me much trouble as I have also read about some reviews that after some time, some of them don't work...

Just an update today Oct 18 that will help whoever having some technical problem with DLink IP camera. I got a new replacement camera from Dlink and decided to put a USB fan behind it to keep it cool at all times. True enough it has not failed till today, suggesting that the hardware is not suitable for tropical high temp conditions unless an external cooling aid is introduced. ====================== Hi, is your DCS2630 still working fine after these few months? I bought one last week end. It worked beautifully for 3 solid days. Then it stopped working. The LED at the rear of the camera is solid green, meaning it is connected to the router, and the router log confirms so. But on MyDllink Lite I see a black screen --> no video streaming.    Did a hard reset by pulling out and plugging back the USB power connector, and it worked again. But only for a day.  Black screen happened again. Need to do reset again. DLink service support says send it back to them for a check, but I guess it will work in their air conditioned lab and it will just be returned to me as is. I believe overheating and burn-out of electronic parts inside the camera is the main cause of the problem. The SDCard is finger burning hot when I pull it out from its slot. Anyone with the same experience as I? I believe overheating and burn-out of electronic parts inside the camera is the main cause of the problem. The SDCard is finger burning hot when I pull it out from its slot. Anyone with the same experience as I? using 1 myself for months. still working with no overheating issues. not in air conditioned room

Hi guys, Could you please recommend me a good NAS to get for home use? (mainly for family photos, movies and docs) Planning to get one this COMEX. My requirements are as follows: Fast transfer speed especially over wifi Good user interface on mobile app Able to show thumbnails on the app (for photos) - My current WD can't. Directly load movies from NAS to TV (if possible) Set up personal shared folders for different users I've been using the WD MyBook Live for a few years and I want to upgrade now. Thinking of getting Synology / QNAP as they seem to be the market choice now. But I'm not sure how it works ah - how many bays should I get and where is the best place to get the HDs? I understand I need to buy it separately? What RAID configuration to use? I only need 2-4TB for now and my budget for the NAS itself is about 200-400 or so. Appreciate if you could recommend me a good model. Thanks a lot!

Most of the Synology, Qnap, asustor NAS are quite similarly priced. If you want fast wifi network speed connect the NAS directly to main router. Do not use any wireline or wifi to connect the NAS. For faster transfer between NAS to PC both need to be as close as possible network wise. I would recommend to go for a NAS which allows you to upgrade RAM and maybe offer a free ram upgrade on NAS purchase. Asustor AS3102T looks pretty good although ram is not upgradable. But has a pretty good processor and 4k video play support. Qnap 251+ although expensive offer ram upgrade and plex capable processor Synology options for intel processors and same specs seem to be bit more expensive as nothing in the price even offers 2gb ram with an intel processor.For example DS216+II offers only 1 GB ram. I have 16gb installed on my NAS. Overkill maybe but I find it to be a very good performance boost.

Thanks for the reply! Will also look at Asustor then! Yup, my NAS is connected directly to the main router. How important is RAM for NAS though? And what NAS are you currently using? Sorry, I am quite a noob when it comes to this NAS thingy haha

CrunchTime wrote: Thanks for the reply! Will also look at Asustor then! Yup, my NAS is connected directly to the main router. How important is RAM for NAS though? And what NAS are you currently using? Sorry, I am quite a noob when it comes to this NAS thingy haha Mine is a QNAP TS-563. Ram upgrade depends on your usage for the NAS. Minimum I would say is 2gb if you plan to use it more than just a data storage device. Mine runs a full Plex server which can stream movies to me on any device. Has 1 VM running linux and has a CCTV connected to it. If you plan to play videos and other applications I would say more ram would definitely help. You don't need something like my 16gb.
i m eyeing for asustor 6204t the spec look good 6404t perfect but too expensive

6204 looks pretty good HDMI 4k output, AES-IN processor (although I would never recommend encryption as its just too slow). Upgradable ram. Raid 5 always makes more sense than Raid 1 for a 2 bay NAS. Setup 4 disks and you have 1 drive failure safety.

Appreciate if you could recommend me a good model. Thanks a lot! Usinga  similar setup Synology for me as it ticks all the right boxed PHOTO / VIDEO Depending on workflow. IF You are the sort who just likes to dump to a watchfolder, you will end up using the built in NAS workflow to handle photos. But if you manually upload to somewhere, GoogleDrive can't be beat. STREAMING to tv I find the TV built in app too restrictive. I ended up putting a Nuc mounted on the wall under each TV. They access the NAS shared folder Same thing for photos. You will understand what i mean when you have alot of family members gathered to watch your baby photo presentation, and you are trying to access the shared folder, but because of the limited cpu power of the smart tv, all you get is th revolving NOW LOADING sign, with you thinking of excuses to stall for time. For your usage, a cheapo 2 bay ought to be fine. Though if you are in the mood to spend over $400 for the enclosure alone, youmight want to take a look at the mid range 4 bay models. The difference is that the mid range offers transcoding. the Cheapos do not. ( for synology ), which is no big deal since the PC just accesses the shared folder, even for wifi....

Beware though. Consumer level NASes eg. WD tend not to have an onboard flash to store your NAS operating system. You don't want to be caught with your pants down if 2 or the entire drive array fails or you opt for a 2/4 drive upgrade to a higher capacity, later find out that the whole NAS can't boot due to the OS that's embedded in the RAID array. Reputable NASes (Synology/QNAP/Thecus) has a form of onboard flash - separate from the disk array. I'd stay away from Seagate / WD / Buffalo NASes. I had quite a bad experience rebuilding an entire Terastation due to the above problem.

No.1 problem is rising costs. Something has got to give and it now solely focusses on the true reason to hold these shows - to move inventory and create sales. I bought the ux430un during cny promo. Did a sheet ton of research on ultralight with mx150. Let me share with you all. Ux331un - this IS Touch screen. It show 1510$. Gpu is nerfed out of the box with lower clock speed and will burst less than other mx150. Gpu thermal throttles at 73. Poor cooling. Ux430un - I got this cause the screen is abit bigger than 13.3" so it'll be easier to see while still being light at 1.25. Gpu also throttles at 73. Also poor cooling. HP envy 13 - mx150 also nerfed. Will also thermal throttle. Lenovo 720s 14 - the only one with proper cooling and doesn't throttle. But 1.55kg. Bonus - xiaomi notebook air: mx150 nerfed, will thermal throttle. 73 degrees thermal limit. Bonus Asus s410un - can't find any info on this from eng language sites. Only French forums. From what I gather, thermal limit 80 degrees. Not sure how their cooling is like. 1.4kg Basically, all the lightweight 1.3 kg and below ultralight notebooks suffer from either downclocked mx150, low thermal limit, poor cooling and will perform about 25 to 30% lousier than the full performance mx150s with proper cooling found in laptops like the lenovo 720s 14", Acer swift 3(1.7kg) and xiaomi notebook pro (2kg)
I been using 116 since last sep and happy with it. Not perfect but good enough for normal usage.

Reborns can do some 3dmark time spy tests? I spent the whole of yesterday and today tinkering with undervolts on my ux430un using Intel xtreme utility (UV the cpu and igpu) and msi afterburner (UV the mx150). Stock 3dmark time spy score: 793 Undervolt CPU: 909 Undervolt CPU+Intel HD: 1034 Use MSI Afterburner to UV MX150 (this one took the longest time and had to trial and error ALOT): 1100-1146 highest. After I did all these I realised I forgot to set my mx150 to max performance mode (default was set to optimal power). So means I got to rerun one more run with my best settings but I will do it Tmr. Witcher 3 all low 720p (also forgot to set to max performance), I went from 18-22 fps stock to 30-40+ fps with quite frequent dips to 11-20ish due to thermal throttling. Setting to max performance nvidia power management on my UV setup I was getting high 30s to 50s with dips. Also ordered some thermal grizzly kryonaut for thermal repaste and will probably order a fuji poly thermal pad.

Any difference between wifi repeater and extender? Btw...will we need to set password for the repeater or extender? I m new to this...m hoping that my phone or tablet can auto detect the strongest signal wherever u r in the house

slang wrote: Any difference between wifi repeater and extender? Btw...will we need to set password for the repeater or extender? I m new to this...m hoping that my phone or tablet can auto detect the strongest signal wherever u r in the house They are technically the same but marketed in a different name. Extender sounds nicer, but they basically re-broadcast the signal, hence "repeater". If you buy the repeater with WPS button, then you can press on both the router and the repeater to sync the SSID. Once done, then your wireless extender is ready to work. But I do not like this method as it may not achieve optimal connectivity. Alternatively smartphone app to walk through the steps to set up easily. Brands like D-Link have apps to let you configure through step by step, allow you to set different SSID and password. Some tips to ensure your wireless extender achieves fast speed: 1. Your wireless router must already be of high spec. Typically, wireless extender will drop the speed by half. 2. Connect the extender to 5GHz frequency to attain higher speed. 3. Place the extender in a good location where it can receive good signal from the router, e.g. place it in the first or second room from the living room where the router is located. 4. Extender must be relatively high spec, e.g. AC1200 and above. I currently use D-Link DAP-1720 as a extender to D-Link DIR-895L. Works very well, it also comes with LAN port which I connect to my desktop in my study room. Before that, I was using homeplugs. I started off with Aztech 500Mbps, but it only give me 80Mbps, which I accepted it as a way of life due to my old condo wiring. Then last year, I tested the TP-Link TL-WPA8730 , which I tested and achieved about 200Mbps when plugged directly to wall socket (even though the app claims I get full 1200Mbps throughput). Unfortunately, my study room no space to plug the homeplug directly, so I had to plug to extension cord, and I ended up getting 120Mbps, which is not too bad (the app shows throughput drops to 230Mbps). Now that I have DAP-1720, I plugged the desktop directly to the LAN port and I attained above 300Mbps. Very happy. I felt that the DAP-1720 extender works better than the WPA8730 extender, in terms of speed as well as signal strength. Disclaimer: D-Link and TP-Link products are on long-term loan to me as a product reviewer-blogger. I share my experience and I use these products for months. I am not paid to write for any brands, so hope you appreciate my sharing of my experience here. If you want to read my reviews in details, you can visit my blog and read further on each of the above products.

For anyone who has bought or intending to buy a Dell monitor, here's something to share about warranty registration. 1) Warranty registration is done online. You need to check for Service Tag number behind your monitor. As per norm, you will need to submit your name, address, contact no, etc. 2) The warranty registration CAN be completed. However, for some reason, it WON'T be recognised by Dell. (wonder where all my info has gone) 3) After more than 48h (the time for Dell to reflect your product registration), you can check your Warranty Status online. You need to input the Service Tag to check. 4) You will realise that no matter how many times you key in the Service Tag, your warranty status cannot be found. 5) I then call up Dell at 1800 3947486. Dell does not seem to have email support. You have to call them. I cannot find anywhere email address on their website. 6) Now, this part is very important. Beside your receipt or invoice, you NEED to keep the box (I hope you have not thrown them away). 7) Dell will not recognise your warranty based on retailer's receipt alone. You must present them the box which must show Order Number starting with 9xxxxx. 8) If you throw the box away and only keep the receipt, Dell may compromise and give you standard warranty of 3 yrs. However, the 3 yrs warranty will not be from your date of purchase, but from the date of Product Manufacture Date! So, if you bought a monitor that is manufactured 2 years ago, you only have 1 year warranty left. This is only for monitors. Laptop wise, I have no idea. The above are my personal experience and hope it clarifies the warranty registration process and what you need to keep.

While my personal experience is not exactly like yours, Dell does have some weird way of going about their warranty claims. I had previously purchased 2 x 24 inch Dell LCD monitors, with an extended 5 year warranty. When they were delivered, the invoice was noted as 3 years warranty. I called/emailed to inform them of the mistake, and they later issued another invoice with the correct warranty information. In the 4th year, the built-in SD card reader didn't work anymore, and I made a warranty claim. Dell claimed that the warranty was only 3 years, so would not be doing any warranty exchange. They kept on using the old (and wrong) 3 year warranty invoice to support their claim. I sent them a copy of my 5 year warranty invoice. They exchanged the faulty LCD monitor. So just keep whatever invoice they send along with your purchased item. Obviously check that the invoice has all details and specifications correctly noted.

@Chalkycliffs Did you buy directly from Dell? I bought from Courts at the PC show at MBS. All I got was a receipt, no invoice. The Dell CSO only recognise the Order Number and nothing else. My monitor had a 5yr warranty too, but the CSO keep insisting on 3yr. Haha. Luckily, I still kept the box which had the words "5 yr Warr" printed on a small sticker. In the end, I got the Order Number they wanted, and was given 5yr warranty. Got to say, Dell should really print the words "keep the box" big big, so customers will be aware of it. I wonder how many people actually keep the box after purchases. The box is not small either, so space consuming! And I have to keep it for the next 5 yrs.
I bought directly from Dell. I keep my LCD monitor boxes, only because it is easier to move the monitors around. They are quite heavy!

Posted with Samsung Galaxy S7 edge HardwareZone Forums app Like you said, raw speed isn't so important. What you didn't say is, latency and packet loss are more important. https://www.imda.gov.sg/applications/rbs/chart.html See the latency and packet loss section, it's typically both around the same, or M1 is lower (aka better). What this aspect shows actually? M1 don't focus so much on raw speed, but focus on what matters most, the real world loading performance. You don't operate the servers, and therefore the need for fastest upload/download is just good to see. Download big files from faraway overseas servers? Still bound to their allocated bandwidth per customer, and most don't give speeds >100Mbps anyway. Most super speed download/upload servers are local/regional CDNs, and therefore speed is more important. In that sense, M1's broadband isn't so far off from SingNet's.

So thank you AMD. https://hothardware.com/news/intel-c...benchmark-leak

symbiote28 wrote: anyone bought the blasterx katana? your reviews? thanks. I been using it for about a month, bought from lazada. Space wise, the sound bar is a bit long but it fits quite nice under my 27 inch monitor. The inconvenient thing is that i have to keep power on the soundbar everything i switch on my pc. The woofer part is the one which i like, as it fits my current table placement. Its slim and able to sit on the legs underneath my table. Other woofer is quite squarish, this one is slim and upright, perfect size for me. Sound wise, its pretty loud and clear. I am not an audiophile, but quality sounds good for me, in gaming, movies and even youtube. Oh yeah, theres different lighting setup for different modes, like orange led for cinema, blue for gaming etc. As i often switch between between gaming and movies, i find it quite troublesome to manually switch the soundbar mode everytime. If only its automatic, it would be good.

Purchased ASUS Zenbook UX410UQ-GV024T at PC Show 2017 on 03/06/2017 (Sat). To me, ASUS has always been great in producing reasonable pricing ultrabooks based on specifications and design. I have always wanted to get a ASUS Zenbook UX410UQ (to replace my HP Pavilion DV4 which has been serving me for at least 8 years) after hearing so much good reviews from the guys in hwz in the IT Show 2017. My decision to purchase this laptop was only made after visiting the PC Show and CEE for 3 days. On 1st June, I have went to both PC Show and CEE to take a look on all the laptops and have fixed my mind to get ASUS Zenbook UX410UQ due to the reasonable pricing and its ability to further upgrade ram and harddisk although it is an ultrabook. On 2nd June, I have went to CEE to enquire on the UX410UQ price since most forumers mentioned CEE has the best price and are more open to negotiations. Although the prices in CEE are really attractive, I was thinking to give a try at PC Show, hoping to get even a more better price. On 3rd June, I went to the PC Show and surprisingly, the ASUS promoter from BD gave me an incredible price. During that time I was pretty unsure if I am hearing the right thing since it is very noisy. However once the promoter wrote the price on the brochure, I immediately told him I will get one from him without thinking twice. I strongly believed I really got the best price for the ASUS UX410UQ-GV024T. I will like to thank the promoter for the "unbelievable" price and I really glad I made the right choice to give the retailers in PC Show a chance to prove that they can sell cheaper than CEE. Overall, I am glad I have finally got my dream laptop at an unbelievable" price! Thank to PC Show, CEE and HWZ.

1. Asus VX228H monitor, from CEE, a good budget monitor which suits what I needed, not too big and 1ms respond time. 2. SteelSeries Heroes of the Storm Gaming Mouse, from CEE, hoot it because I believe it is a good deal, had a SteelSeries Rival Dota2 Edition used for 3-4 years and I think it's time to change a new one. 3. TV Box, from PC Show, hoot for my mom, negotiated until a good price which I believe lower than any qoo10 listing 4. SteelSeries Apex M650 Keyboard, from CEE, as a mechanical keyboard collector I can say this is the most beautiful RGB keyboard I ever purchase, pretty good deal too.

Bought this microsoft bluetooth mobile mouse 3600 from challenger at CEE 2017. I chose to purchase this as I was looking for a good quality bluetooth mouse for quite a while now and the prices at CEE was much lower than the retail price!

1) 2) Bought the Lenovo Yoga 710 from the Challenger booth at CEE! Heard that CEE had better offers than PC Show so headed down to Suntec 3) Read good reviews about this particular model and decided to get it for uni! Also because it has most of the specs I was looking for + touch screen, 360 hinge, lightweight and slim bezel are huge plus for the price I paid!

Got quite a bit of stuff, all at the PC show last weekend! First of all, I got a new Epson L655 from the pc show I am starting uni soon, and my faithful Epson L355, which has served me faithfully for nearly 4 to 5 years, had started to complain about ink pads being full, and the print quality was starting to dip. Since my previous Epson L series printer has done so well, and I had spare bottles of Epson coloured ink (these ink bottles seriously take nearly 10 months to actually finish!), I decided to take on its more advanced brother, the Epson L655. It not only gives quality, cheap printing, but now also makes the black prints waterproof (with its slightly more expensive black ink formula), adds on an auto-document feeder (ADF) and now I can swiftly send any documents I scan to my email seamlessly! For the price (and amount of documents I foresee to print when uni starts),  it's a great bargain and a no brainer to continue with Epson L series ink tanks! Before the Epson  l355 which I used before, I was using a HP photostat printer - and had to buy all colour and black ink cartridges every quarter - thus costing me 100 per trip and spending nearly 400 dollars per year on ink alone. It was crazy. Never looked back once I swapped to Epson's ink tank printers. I switched the moment it was sold in the pc show. I remember only filling up the l355's ink tanks 3 times in 4 years. Since the first fill was free (a full bottle of each colours ink is included), this meant that over 4 years, I spent 90 dollars TOTAL for ink. Best investment ever! Beat that HP! My second purchase in the pc show is a HP Omen! I wanted a laptop which was fast and responsive, Could do some light duty gaining and not break the bank. This laptop model filled my needs perfectly! Featuring a quad core i7 processor, a free upgrade to 16gb ram and a full 512GB ssd drive in it, it, to me, was the model TO GET. at 1669 with a free bump to 3 years warranty, i got it immediately. I imagine that the laptop would be a beast when multitasking and working on uni projects, and would fulfill my gaming needs as well (since I am a casual (racing) gamer and I don't want to fork out obscene amounts of cash just for racing on the need for speed Race tracks). I'm not convinced that it is the best deal around (since I didn't cross check with many other booths), but I'm sure this was one of the better deals. Oh. And just look at the red glowing backlit keyboard! O-Men, this makes the laptop look good as well! And finally my 3rd purchase - the creative iroar! Let me show of its size against the faux carbon fibre hood of my Hp omen... The old creative soundblaster roar 1 has served me well all these years (I was one of the fee to purchase it when it was first released), and this time, creative has not only lowered it's asking price for the creative iRoar (the 3rd generation successor in the roar series), but also done a trade in opportunity as well! Together with the voucher discount (actually you don't need a voucher, just ask their salesperson for a free voucher&#128514 , and $100 trade in for the old roar, I spent only 199 to get my hands on an iRoar. Believe me when I say this one was a massive improvement - louder sound, better bass and killer battery life, all coming from a small dictionary sized package! No regrets Other thoughts: I didn't go to the CEE, and went straight for the pc show even though some said the laptop deals in CEE were great. That was because the big boys like creative weren't in CEE. I personally felt these 2 shows shouldn't have been held at the same time. It's just splitting the crowd and and causing unnecessary confusion among consumers. As a comparatively newer show, the CEE should be held either before or after the pc show. If consumers feel it's worth it,I'm sure they could have gone for the CEE. But by holding both on the same day and effectively splitting the crowd, experienced hands like me will skip CEE altogether and just go for the tried and tested PC Show exhibition. Where got time to go to 2 shows?! Just my 2 cents.

1) Dell P2317H monitor 2) Bought at PC Show at MBS, from Courts. 3) Reason for getting this, was that my age cannot see well on a small screen. So decided to get a monitor. As for the brand, I was deciding between Asus and Dell. Decided on Dell in the end because it can adjust height too.

1) ASUS Vivobook S510 2) Purchased at PC Show 2017, Gain City Booth 3) I previously had a ASUS U45JC laptop and it has served me well for the past 7 years. I decided to go ahead with a ASUS laptop this time round as I have a good impression with ASUS brand. I mainly use my laptop to watch dramas/movies and browse the internet. After doing some research, I decided on the ASUS Vivobook S510. It is a very slim, lightweight and stylish laptop. The screen boasts a full HD 15.6 inch display with an ultrathin benzel and I like this aspect of the laptop the most as a good screen is essential for watching movies, and coupled with ASUS's SonicMaster technology, I really enjoy watching movies on my new laptop now. Despite its slim form, the laptop also manages to pack in a Nvidia GeForce GTX940 discrete graphics and a 1TB mechanical hard drive. To top it off, the laptop is powered by the latest 7th-generation Intel Core i7 processor. Last but not least, it is also a laptop which I can easily carry around and use on the go. I have been using my laptop for the past couple of days now and my overall impression so far: Amazing laptop, excellent value for money! I am extremely pleased with my purchase.

bladez87 wrote: 100Mbps cable broadband @ $19.90/month No Contract starhub is cable broadband the same as fiber? using the same connection point? No. Cable broadband use coaxial point as same as TV point which is only from Starhub. Fibre use Fibre Terminal Point which is installed by NetLink Trust (NLT) only.

Last year the GP battery staff told me to use the GP 8 hours battery charger (included in the above $11.8 pack) as follows : - connect it to your mobile phone charger via its micro-USB port. - charge them before going to sleep. - next morning when you wake up, the batteries will be fully charged. - the charger will auto-cut off the charging current when batteries are fully charged. So it is not really necessary to buy the more expensive quick charger pack. But of course, it does offer the extra flexibility if you're in a hurry. Good buy too.

If you open mouth ask for 3 years you can likely get -HP provided carrying case, most likely can get them throw in -The warranty extension etc are likely HP gifts as well than from retailer -Wireless mouse (retailer - generic brand?) most probably can get them throw in without affecting their margin much Stuff like nonsense freebies can decline (maybe insist on the cheapo mouse freebie cause it costs them like nothing), work your way easier up to a lower quote, imo cash discount more important. Depending on stocks, wouldn't hurt asking if pay by cash/nets can have any further discount than taking the respective 0% installment schemes. But overall need to check price from each retailer, find a part timer sales guy that's willing to open mouth ask the supervisor. To answer a few questions in this post: 1) ux410 only has rose gold for the current models (gv015t and gv024t). I didnt see other colours unless gv041t (older model) that has silver. Personally, i like the 430 grey, but thats only for the i5 models. No grey yet for the i7 models. So yeah, i am stuck with rose gold. 2) I bought the gv024t from a shop with the initials HN, cus i didnt want the freebies (to clarify: these are HN extra freebies, not the asus standard freebies which i was still given). HN has freebies worth 180 (or worth 200 if you are looking at the gv015t model) which you can use to select your own gifts combinations (ram upgrade, external hdd, thumb drive, microsoft office 365/home edition/etc, etc - each has a pricelist). 3) I bought mine at 1,208. Wont be pasting screenshot of invoice, but thats what i paid. Note, remember i said even same shop has different pricing (depends on who you talk to). Also note that this was today's price and i am not sure if pc fair will adjust their pricing tomorrow. Note: HN pwp for microsoft office is not the cheapest for home & student edition. Its at $188 as compared to $169 in other shops. For 1,398 (gv024t), you can get it with microsoft home & student edition at C (not courts), or less 169 if you dont want it. 4) 530 series is heavier but slightly better specs. I was considering this as well. But then again, 530 may be coming soon. In the end, i bought one that i think is most cost efficient (for me). 5) yeah, ux410 has currently has at least 4 series (from different shops i saw in sg - gv015, gv024, gv041, gv064). Current models are gv015 and gv024 at current prices. Some shops have older models at higher prices that they trying to clear (i.e., marking up the price to subsequenlty slash down to show is promo or give freebies - all to unsuspecting buyers). The older models are priced slightly higher by asus.

No. Lenovo's ODM is normally Wistron (formerly contract manufacturing arm of acer) including Thinkpads for quite awhile. If you disassembled your own you can find the stamped markings over the interiors of the laptop. Wistron is a larger OEM and Foxconn stuff are a hit or miss. 4 year old thinkpad still working perfectly less one fan breakdown incident (common lenovo fan error). Asus uses Foxconn mostly. Consumer laptop build quality and QC are different from pro line, do not conflate. Also driver support you're looking at less than one year on consumer products and are in general more prone to planned obsolesence . While pro grade ones they'll have upgrades and fixes for years. There are some hardware in my thinkpad that are just Windows 7/10 compatible officially (even from hardware vendors like Intel), but for pro laptops they've extended the support to windows 10. Its a different ball game where consumer notebooks are more price performance oriented while pro laptops are focused on build quality and long term support including part availability. TPM security chip built in and there's option for smart card for some corporate requirements.

It didn't go out of stock during the PC Show actually. At least, there was no indication that stocks were running low when I bought mine around 7.30pm on Sunday. I originally went on Thursday but the rep told me stocks would only arrive on Saturday. I actually intended to ask for the display set in hopes of at least a $200 discount (I had all along planned to get the FHD version with lower specs, alas they only launched the one with the highest specs), but there was no display set at the booth and anyway they offered me $200 off for a new set. I figured since it just launched (in fact the manufacturing date on the box was 28 May - just 1 week before I bought it!), if there is any discount 3 months later at Comex, it's unlikely to be much more. And by then I would have gotten enough use to make up for the difference in price. (Not to mention I almost got the Yoga 710 at the IT Show until I saw the announcement for the Yoga 720 - it was supposed to release in April - and decided to wait. It's been 2 months and I'm not willing to wait another 3!) Important note though: the Lenovo Active Pen 2 is actually included in the box. I was very surprised as all the reviews I read from overseas purchasers mentioned that their unit did not come with a pen; in fact the Active Pen 2 is not even on the market yet.

I believe Amazon and Bestbuy do ship direct to singapore for some items. For huge and heavy items, I prefer to go through an agent like ezbuy.com. Why? because the shipment cost is a lot lot lot cheaper!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! So i buy the item and ask amazon, bestbuy to ship to the agent US address. Shipment within US is normally free. And then I would use the ship-for-me service in ezbuy to ship to Singapore. Note: ezbuy offers 2 services: ship-for-me and buy-for-me. I would normally use ship-for-me. This is the cheapest for most cases. HP and Dell (and maybe others) do offer international warranty. https://support.hp.com/us-en/document/bpr01266 https://www.dell.com/support/assets-...en/4#/Identify However, i have not used those services yet ... and hopefully not going to.
I forgotten to mention amazon do provide free shipment for some items. I bought a 4T Seagate Barracuda hdd for US$99 + some other items and shipped to me free.

Bought a lenovo laptop last year, as far as i know, the warranty for the laptop is registered as soon as it leaves the production factory, thus the earlier date (or so i was told by the Lenovo sales rep). You have to write in an email to their warranty support with the receipt of your laptop from the date you purchased it and they'll change the start date for the warranty to the date of purchase.

I've always had this problem with my past 3 Lenovo laptops.  Just email them and have it changed.  They seem to initially capture the shipping date instead of the consumer purchase date. My sets were all brand new.

dell se2717h $219 vs LG 27MP58 $289 which is better?

absolutepitch828 wrote: dell S2717H $229 dell s2718H $439 this one not really budget. but would be good if someone can update if vesa mount compatible. cant find the specifics anywhere online I got both the Dell S2718H and S2717H. The S2718H has a glass panel finishing, so you will get some light reflection, how much (bad) will depends on where you place the monitor, thinner bezel, more solid-looking and has provision behind for wall-mounting bracket. The S2717H is cheaper, like someone said, can get at $219 from Lazada (I got it at exactly $219, from Lazada too). It is matt-screen, so there is no light reflection problem, good for doing work (Word, Excel etc..) not that vibrant for video. There is not provision for wall mount at its back. And finally, it has a cheapo-plastic feel to it. Doesn't feels like a Dell, feels more like a unknown brand monitor with a Dell logo stick on it. But it is a Dell. I can't really do a side-by side comparison because the S21718H is at my workplace and the S2717H is at home. Both monitors' height cannot be adjusted, you can only tilt them.

Frederic93 wrote: XG32VQ is 100x100 as well, but not sure if any adapter needed For a VESA 100 x 100mm, it is between centre of hole to hole under international standards. But the distance from edge of hole to edge of VESA plate is undefined and thus makers may make it bigger or smaller. I experienced a similar case whereby my wall mount plate was unable to fit into my current samsung S27D850T. The plate's overall dimension is slightly bigger than the VESA hole in the monitor. But when i use Prism+ ARC desk mount, the plate was able to fit in with some allowance as the overall dimensions are slightly smaller than the VESA hole in the monitor. For the C32HG70, Samsung provided an adaptor so as to fit VESA plates. The VESA part will protrube out of the monitor so it should not be an issue. But for the ASUS one, the VESA hole is circular which is a concern for me. Dear Experts, Need your expert advice on the following issues. Bought a laptop from a particular vendor at the IT show. (1) Was advised that the local warranty given by themselves is 3 months. But upon researching after purchase, I realized the original product warranty (manufacturer based in HK) is 1 year.  My question is are the local retailers allowed to give a shorter warranty as they deem fit? - I cannot use the HK warranty because it says it is not available for overseas merchandise, something along that line. (2) The original packaging is supposed to come with a free TF/sd card. But during the show the sales person said that it does not come with it - sure at least he/she was upfront about it. And true enough when I opened the packaging at home the TF/sd card was already removed from the packaging (even though there is a sticker saying TF card inside).  Are these local retailers allowed to amend the contents of the packaging? Can I demand for the items to be complete or ask for refund instead? Also, how do I check and ensure that the product I receive is not a refurbished (or used) item? What do I look out for? Internally (software) or externally (seals, etc). Appreciate all your help.

ThrowAway01 wrote: Dear Experts, Need your expert advice on the following issues. Bought a laptop from a particular vendor at the IT show. (1) Was advised that the local warranty given by themselves is 3 months. But upon researching after purchase, I realized the original product warranty (manufacturer based in HK) is 1 year.  My question is are the local retailers allowed to give a shorter warranty as they deem fit? - I cannot use the HK warranty because it says it is not available for overseas merchandise, something along that line. (2) The original packaging is supposed to come with a free TF/sd card. But during the show the sales person said that it does not come with it - sure at least he/she was upfront about it. And true enough when I opened the packaging at home the TF/sd card was already removed from the packaging (even though there is a sticker saying TF card inside).  Are these local retailers allowed to amend the contents of the packaging? Can I demand for the items to be complete or ask for refund instead? Appreciate all your help. 1) Yes, they can. It's called parallel goods. Manufacturer's warranty doesn't apply for parallel goods. Even if they have a local office, they will not honour the warranty if it's not a local set. Any personal warranty given by the seller is up to them, they can even not give any personal warranty. You can only kpkb and make noise if they misled you into thinking its a local set and covered by local manufacturer warranty 2) If they already told you about any missing stuffs with the package, and you opt to deal with them anyway, then there's nothing you can complain about with regards to the said missing content. Generally I would only deal with this kind of retailers with paralllel goods if the price is really, really attractive.

Not sure if they are at the fair, but I recently got a xiaoyi (mind you it's not xiaomi despite the similarity in names) Ultra Dash cam going at $169 before applying discount coupon. Heard about several good reviews on it before deciding to go for this and no regrets. Used it for 2 days and quality is really decent. Records at max 60fps. Can download an app and view or download video to your phone. Or use the screen to review videos or change settings. In built battery able to record for a few minutes without external power supply. The built of the cam is solid and pleasantly high quality for a PRC brand. Other two versions are the Dash cam and Smart Dash cam.
Another deal maker for me which made me go for it is it's 28nm chips which basically means better power efficiency.

I just bought the Lenovo IdeaPad 720s 15-IKB and IMO it is by far the most value for money high performance Notebook. From what I know, this 15" model was just released a few days ago. I doubt it is available in stores yet. Many people aren't aware it exist here in SG. RRP is $2199 but surprisingly for a brand new model, you can bargain down quite a bit. It has features and specs almost identical to the Dell XPS 15 9560 (1080p) Model. 15.6" FHD Matte Bezel-less Non-Touch Display Core i7-7700HQ 2.8GHz 16GB DDR4 2400MHz Ram 512GB PCIe SSD GTX 1050Ti Max-Q 4GB DDR5 Fingerprint Reader Webcam at the TOP of the "bezel-less" screen. 9 Hours of Battery Life (79Wh Battery) 1.9KG/1.7CM Thin Don't get me wrong, this isn't perfect. Firstly, there are limited ports. There's only 1 USB Type-A port, Micro SD Card Slot, 3.5mm jack, 1 Thunderbolt 3 port and a Type-C 3.1 port. No HDMI or Full Size SD Card slot. Secondly, build quality is marginally worse (Slightly more Flex) than the XPS 15. Overall, if you don't mind living a dongle life, this is one you should consider.

Claire C at 12:12, Mar 14: If you will re-contract today with Singtel, there is no other charges since your contract is eligible to re-contract today and it is already reached 23 months. Claire C at 12:12, Mar 14: However, for other Telco, I cannot guarantee it. You at 12:13, Mar 14: Putting penalty incurred by the other Telco aside, what will Singtel charge to me if I port to other Telco before 9 April 2017? Claire C at 12:15, Mar 14: I understand that you want to know more about the charges however, I cannot guarantee it now online since Singtel will be the one who will communicate to other Telco to port in your number. You at 12:17, Mar 14: Does a porting consider premature cancellation before minimum subscription period? Claire C at 12:19, Mar 14: As far as we know, this is only for customers who want to cancel their existing plan.However, if you want to know more charges about porting to another service provided, I recommend you to contact our Singtel Hotline at 1688. How much Recovery Fee / Penalty / Miscellaneous Fees do I have to pay, according to my existing plan? Claire C at 12:23, Mar 14: A recovery fee of $38 is required. Tl,dr: - For a 26-day early termination of Combo 2, Singtel charges $38 Recovery Fee and No Early Termination Penalty . - Porting fee is subject to the next telco's (in this case, M1's) discretion. - No incentive for being loyal ( M1 offers $150 off for port-in to 1Lite+ package , but Singtel simply told me that no discount at the moment and kept hardselling something that I don't want at all). As of now, without considering Caller Number Display, Admin Fee, SIM Card Fee, and Porting Fee, M1 package is at $1389 while Singtel package is at $1547.44. Need to confirm these fees in both M1 shop and ITSHOW (no CORI application available via online).

Recovery fee is indirectly contract termination charges. M1 charges $30/mth for that for i/Lite+ plan if contract not fully fulfilled. i-Lite+ CIS gets $150 discount as part of the promotion. SIM Card, Line Registration (total worth $48.15) for CIS is free. Caller ID and AutoRoam (total worth $16.05/mth) should be free too. CIS discount depends on your company. There is no such thing known as porting charge for the four carriers (Including Circles.Life). The CIS/CORI for M1 is Shop/CSC only, M1 website don't handle it. Idk about IT Show.

I also had the ASUS RT-N66U. It is a serious bottleneck for the 300Mbps Fibre over WiFi, that's why I had to upgrade to ASUS RT-AC1200G+. RT-AC1200G+ on 2X2 AC WiFi is up to 380Mbps, can't reach 500Mbps but much closer already. Mobile on 802.11ac also get considerable speed boost, >250Mbps for capable devices. FYI: RT-N66U over 2X2 802.11n 5GHz WiFi can only get up to 240Mbps. 2X2 MIMO configuration is for laptops, for mobile it is mostly up to 120Mbps only due to 1X1 configuration. (I upgraded to the RT-AC1200G+, knowing that it will be capable of getting the full 300Mbps Fibre. No point getting AC68U/88U with the speed tbh.) kopicgao wrote: Oh dear! Thanks for pointing it out. Any idea what will be the real speed if use AC1200 on 500Mbps plan? https://www.asus.com/sg/Networking/R...pecifications/ What does data rate mean 802.11n : up to 300 Mbps 802.11ac : up to 867 Mbps ? Unable to find how many Mbps RT-AC1200 support when using wired connection. ~280Mbps max for 802.11ac enabled mobile phones. ~380Mbps max for 802.11ac enabled 2X2/3X3 MIMO devices (e.g. laptops/desktops). Not full 500Mbps over WiFi because it can't reach, but even with AC68U, your devices will be the bottleneck (most only support 1X1 / 2X2 setup, not 3X3).

If recontract from 1gbps to 500mbps will it affect steam download? Also usually there will be 4 device streaming video, those korean drama etc, will lag? And acestream for football. Anyone who downgraded pls share. Thks

poooooo wrote: If recontract from 1gbps to 500mbps will it affect steam download? Also usually there will be 4 device streaming video, those korean drama etc, will lag? And acestream for football. Anyone who downgraded pls share. Thks There should not have any difference. Video streaming even on 4K only utilises ~50Mbps, and 4X of it is ~200Mbps. Streaming 4K on all machines are not so practical, and the router would be the problem instead because of the high load requirements per client. Since 200Mbps for 4 active 4K streams is required, Full HD 1080p streaming is much lower compared, and therefore there is even lower reason for the lag to happen. I did before 2 4K + 1 FHD YouTube streaming over M1 Fibre 200Mbps, and none of them lagged.

linusz wrote: Anyone broadband not activated yet My 300Mbps was bumped up to 500Mbps maybe within 30mins after i recontract. Speedtest done via LAN.

minute_me wrote: LAN. not sure if the service is activated. speed is really slow. my starhub 100 mbps on LAN can achieve 100MBPS using ASUS RT AC56. my m1 using a very old buffalo  WHR-HP-G300N..... not sure if it's the router slowing down the speed. but then the buffalo supposed to be max speed 300mbps ??? The LAN/WAN max speed for the router is only 100Mbps, aka Fast Ethernet. Even if the router's Wireless performance is up to 300Mbps 802.11n, the bottleneck is the Ethernet speed. Also, 802.11n 2.4GHz band is well known to get speed drops to ~70Mbps or less when the wireless clients includes mobile devices. You've to upgrade to Gigabit Ethernet routers to enjoy the High Speed Fibre Broadband, and preferably a dual-band 802.11ac one for many recent devices to full take advantage over WiFi.

guys will my speed be different if i modem -> lan cable -> pc 1, similarly, modem -> lan cable -> router -> pc2. can this be done? will pc2 and pc1 both running ethernet have same speeds?

ZenTape wrote: Btw apologies for the noobness. I remember there should be one modem inside the d-box (Hdb flat) ya? For that modem is included regardless of whichever m1 plan ya? That's called ONT, Optical Network Terminal. M1 Fibre 300/500Mbps, 1Gbps (HomePac/GamePro/Velop/Razer/Switch) all uses the standard Huawei HG8240/HG8240H ONT. Loan as part of the package, may need to give back after you terminate the contract. ONT \u2260 ONR, therefore the provided ONT doesn't have DHCP capabilities for LAN. M1 Fibre 2/5/10Gbps would be given a better ONT, I'm not too sure what ONT model is that.

etoilebiscuit wrote: guys will my speed be different if i modem -> lan cable -> pc 1, similarly, modem -> lan cable -> router -> pc2. can this be done? will pc2 and pc1 both running ethernet have same speeds? If both are Gigabit Ethernet enabled and the router supports Gigabit Ethernet too, it should be nearly the same for most recent routers. (May have some overheads but differences shouldn't be that big.)
